REVIEW: Jun 21 2008 	boooo	Cathedral Hill was brutal. I stayed there for 9 nights and it was a really big dive. We would have preferred to deal with the commuting than the seedy Cathedral Hill...oh and by the way it is in a location called the 'tenderloin' aka crazy drug addict, tranny, and prostitute area..will never return

Jun 21 2008	Poor location	We stayed here after our tour finished and were just so glad we had spent the main part of our time in San Fran staying at the Radisson on the Wharf.The location of this hotel is very poor - and we walked down Geary Street looking for somewhere to eat and felt a bit nervous (daylight too)The hotel itself is rather nice, very helpful staff and the room was clean and comfortable. There were not really sufficient towels and the flush on the loo was *very* suspect!The computer gave 60 mins for $8 and it loaded quickly which was good.The pool was lovely and tranquil, set in nice gardens but no-one from the hotel around.I like a swim every day and when I went I felt intimidated with a large group of young people doing somersaults, back flips etc and taking over the whole pool.Their language was dreadful and they spent much time loudly discussing which drugs to take to the evening's party!Whilst this is not obviously the fault of the hotel I felt that a person seen to be about might have made it nicer for others.Once this group moved on then it was fine and everyone else felt able to return to the pool.There's not really enough sun loungers and the pool towels are small and rather threadbare.This hotel is a long walk from anywhere particular and the cable cars etc are also not nearby.I would definitely avoid it if I went back to SF and would most definitely stay on the Wharf.Mel's Diner over the road was quite nice, we daren't walk too far in this area looking for an alternative!
Jun 14 2008	Huge rooms and big hotel	The gym is nice. The rooms are huge, and you can see the senery outside very well. Breakfast is not free, but it has two types of prices to choose from.

Jun 11 2008 	Great value and helpful staff	My husband and I spent a week in San Francisco and stayed at the Cathedral Hill Hotel. We saw several negative reviews of the hotel before our trip and were greatly relieved to have a good experience at the hotel. From the moment we checked in until we checked out we found every staff member to be friendly and helpful, something that isn't always the case at much more expensive places. We had a king room which was clean and comfortable. The carpets could stand to be updated but the bed was brand new. At such a low rate, the hotel can't be beat. Some tips if you're going to San Francisco--there is a bus stop in front of the hotel and we bought a 7-day bus pass in the hotel gift shop. Staff was very helpful with directions and suggestions. The concierge arranged tours for us and suggested restaurants within walking distance. There's a great place, "Mel's Drive-in" across from the hotel which is fun and offers good food. Also a good Japanese restaurant a block away. The hotel has an ATM in the lobby and a restaurant plus a take-out coffee shop.

May 20 2008 	OK for a cheap rate. Go nearer Union Square if you can.	Booked this as was looking for good rate for a 4 night stay - was good value. Location OK, but a good 20 minute walk to Union sqaure and 15 minutes to cable cars. Really needs a facelift overall in terms of rooms and back end. Reception is nice comapred to rest. Rooms were clean and staff very nice.

May 9 2008 	Cheap rack rates spacious stingey does the job	The rack rates (about $119) are as good as discounted hotwire or similar rates in other hotels in SF. You can stay at a lot nicer places for the same money if you use a discount booker like hotwire. BUT - that's not always an option, plus it's nice to know in advance where you are staying. So their rates are pretty fine for SF if you don't have the time or inclination to go searching hard.The rooms are spacious and fine. Nothing special. The usual - TV, bathroom with tub, desk, large - VERY firm bed.The location is superb - better than in the main shopping/cable car area in my opinion. We stayed off Taylor / O'Farrel the previous few days, and whilst it's near the cable cars, Van Ness in our opinion is far better located (the cable cars are next to useless - too long a wait). Van Ness runs right down to the Fisherman's Wharf and there are cheap ($1.5) busses running all the time. It;s not a bad walk either - especially the downhill direction :-) - It;s also a 10 minute walk back to the main shopping district on Market St.Also a short bus or walk to the Cow Hollow area for superb restaurants and shopping - very upscale.My major gripe with the Cathedral Hill Hotel is their mean / stingey streak. They really need to get up to date with charges. The extras they charge for and should not do:$12 a day for Internet access (no free hotspots in range) - this should be FREE everywhere now, and mainly is.Room service - Mandetory 15% tip plus $2 extra. This wouldn't be so bad if their menu was not so mean. For example - if you order their burger you pay Extra for onions!!! Extra for cheeese, Extra for pepper - Extra for anything. I mean, come on, paying for onions on a burger.This just reinforces the old reputation hotels had for stitching you up the moment you stepped foot inside. Needless to say we have paid for nothing - ordering food in from outside etc.A small but important thing they need to change. Make the guests feel welcome and inclined to spend money, don't force every cent out of them

Apr 19 2008 	Love this place and the employees	I've stayed here for years, and i love it. The staff is wonderful and the accomadations are impeccable. When in SF, this is my hotel of choice. I love CHH.

Feb 28 2008 	Fantastic Bargain	We live in northern California and travel south to San Francisco several times each year. We often stay near Union Square but this time opted for Van Ness. Feb 11 2008	Never again	My family and I stayed at this hotel which is owned by California Pacific Medical Center and the American Cancer Society when a relative had a kidney transplant. The reservations agent was less than hospitable when I booked, but that could be overlooked if the guest room wasn't shockingly filthy. The first room we were assigned had food reminents and dirt on the walls and the bathroom floor is one I would never walk on without shoes and would rather not walk on with shoes. We asked to switch rooms. The second room had less dirt on the walls but there was scummy dirt on the hair dryer and once again a frightening floor in the bathroom. The website says the rooms have been renovated but a new bed spread, chair, and cutains is not the place to start. The carpet needed to be replaced, there was a brown mystery substance on one of the curtains, an exposed electric socket, the wallpaper is hanging and there was rust all over the bathroom-including a rusted mirror that is bolted to the counter and has seen God knows what in terms of use. I would not recommend this hotel until they actually renovate it. The location was good and the package rate ($89 which included parking, and breakfast buffet) would have been good if I wasn't waiting to catch something from the room. It's appalling to me that a hospital and a nonprofit could allow such filth. I also noticed that comments have been left about the ac units not working back in October 2007-there still not fixed! Stay somewhere else even if it costs more. One more thing-the shuttle to Cal Pacific does not run on weekends and nobody informed the family of this. In fact, the reservations person gave me the times for it and didn't bother to mention that it doesn' t run on the weekends. A couple of family members were waiting for it to come Sat morning. It's @ $7 cab ride to the hospital.

Feb 6 2008 	Great way to ring in the New Year!	The hotel was clean and the employees were courteous. Everyone was extremely friendly and accomodating. Nov 23 2007 	great value would come back!	We booked the hotel through Priceline, and when reading some of the bad reviews, we were tempted to book someplace else... Nov 16 2007 	Clean but that's about it	The hotel is clean, but it's like something out of the 70's. Everything needs to be updated. Can't even control the temperature in the room. Oct 23 2007 	Stay away if you want to get some sleep	Stayed here for two nights while on a brief trip from LA up to San Fran. The location of the hotel is ok, but it's still a good distance from Fisherman's Wharf and Union Square, the main attractions in San Fran. On arriving at the hotel, I checked in at reception and the guy who dealt with my check-in was very unhelpful. We had pulled up in our car right outside the door and did not know where to park it. The guy at reception barely told me where the car park was before shouting "next in line" having already taken my credit card details and getting paid up front for the accommodation. The car park is a nightmare to navigate, one of the worst I've seen and as for trying to get to the hotel lobby from the car park, it's like a maze. We ended up on the 7th floor of an adjoining medical centre, with our heavy luggage in tow, which no-one had offered to help us with and which we had to carry out of the car park up stairs as there were no lifts from our level. The room was adequate for what you pay for, small but sufficient, but the noise is terrible. There is constant street noise, the hotel is located on a block, so there's no avoiding it. The air conditioning is an old-fashioned fan/radiatior which whirrs all night and can't be turned off. The worst thing about the hotel though is the noise. At 5.30am some big-rigs pulled up on the street outside our bedroom window and proceeded to load and unload cargo...beeping and banging for at least an hour. The pool is small and the fitness centre has only 1 treadmill. When we asked to change to another room, a second guy at reception was not very helpful and said "It's a hotel in the city...what can ya do...it's noisy, everywhere is noisy"...great public relations skills there. All in all, it's a big hotel in the San Francisco city and people will be tempted by its location, but pay a bit more at a better hotel, it'll be worth it in the end.

Oct 18 2007 	Cathedral Hill Hotel - pretty good value	I stayed for 2 nights in the Cathedral Hill Hotel. It was pretty good - the room had a small balcony and was quiet and comfortable. Overall the room was clean, and whilst not large, it was good value for money.

Oct 8 2007	OK as a city break	We had read the reviews on this site and were a bit concerned about the state of the rooms. Oct 6 2007 	A good experiemce	The room was slightly dated but very clean. Sep 28 2007 	Clean but scary... and it is not just the hotel.	My husband and I were going on vacation to San Francisco and read some tough reviews on this hotel. I decided though, for the price of $164 US/night, that I would stick it out and make up my own mind as well (something that other reviewers also said). In addition, I thought that the area would still be a prime spot to be in where it was supposedly close to Union Square. All these presumptions were proven wrong when my husband and I arrived. The hotel is indeed in need of a lot of work. You can tell immediately that they are trying to keep it intact for as long as they can without sinking too many funds into overhauling the hotel. The hotel is very outdated and although the rooms are very, very clean, the peeling wallpaper and questionable brown-grey carpet truly show the age of the hotel. The biggest test we placed on the hotel though was taking a walk down to Union Square in the early afternoon going east on Geary. From Van Ness Ave. to about Jones St. my husband and I had 2 thoughts: move fast and MYOB. Now, I'm a seasoned traveler. It's not like I've never seen a homeless person on the street before or someone sketchy that I should walk around and avoid. I have to say though, in this situation we raced through about 5 blocks of complete slum where we saw some pretty scary people and actually felt nervous enough to want to walk fast. After these few blocks the neighborhood finally changes up and does a complete 180 where you start to see some nice art galleries and business folks around. This was the last test before we decided that it was time to switch out to another hotel in Union Square. Truly, the walk from Cathedral Hill Hotel to Union Square was not long (approx. 9 blocks... 15 - 20 minutes) and we would have continued to stay at the Cathedral Hill Hotel for the location and reasonable rate however, given the slummy area we had to cross to get to Union Square and the old looking rooms, it was not worth $164/night. If anything, the rooms are only worth $99 at best and that's already pushing it. We ended up moving to the Hilton on 333 O'Farrell the next day where it was only 5 minutes away from all the shopping you can imagine in Union Square... and the area was much more comfortable to walk in! Overall, if you don't care about the scummy area and can put up with the old rooms then by all means stay at Cathedral. For all of you who are think like we do, take your money elsewhere where you know you will be happy for an extra $70 a night. My husband and I decided that we would truly hate our vacation in San Francisco if we continued to stay at Cathedral Hill Hotel. The last thing we wanted to do was to wreck our own vacation. Sometimes, money isn't everything and all of you should keep this mind if you are about to book at Cathedral Hill Hotel.

Nov 19 2006 	The old Jack Tar Hotel.	I grew up just North of S.F. My mother used to work at the Jack Tar Hotel in the 1950's. It's been the Cathederal Hill Hotel since the 1980's. It has a great parking garage that's free if you stay at the hotel. This is good because if you don't know your way around S.F., PLEASE take taxis or use public transportation. Having grown up with "the city" in my backyard, I can tell you that you will beat on your car driving it in the city. The traffic and the hills are murder on a car... If you can, rent a car.. Then you can go nuts and drive all over the city.The location of the hotel is perfect because it's next door to Tommy's Joynt. Tommy's is a S.F. landmark restaurant and watering hole. I've been going to Tommy's as long as I can remember for lunch with my dad (t)....... Tommy's is a local hangout that you most likely won't find in your "S.F. Tourism Guide" eventhough Tommy's has been in the same location for over 50 years. Everytime I travel back to the bay area for a visit, I make a point of eating at Tommy's Joynt for lunch. I like the Turkey Sandwich with a side of Potato Salad... All meats are hand carved before your very eyes. (Hofbrau style cooking) If you haven't been to Tommy's, You haven't been to S.F..The hotel itself is scheduled for demolition next year, (2007), to make way for a new hospital, so don't expect upgraded plumbing in your room. The lobby and meeting rooms are quite nice. They were having a convention of professional transvestite bowlers when we were there. The conventioneers were a laugh a minute.Overall the hotel is like any other hotel ready for the chopping block. You can find better rooms, but you can't find a better location due to Tommy's Joynt. Don't expect anything special from the rooms. They're old, musty and falling apart, and by next year they litterally will be, via the wrecking ball. But if you're stayingin S.F and like good food, this is a good place to stay because it is soclose to a lot of S.F.'s best places ( If you're a local) to eat. Make sure you eat at Tommy's... Also, House of Prime Rib is a few blocks to the North on Van Ness Ave... You can walk there from the hotel. It's on the opposite side of Van Ness about 8 blocks North. There's very little parking, but Valet is available.. It's within walking distance from the hotel... Do you like Prime Rib? If so, you will love The House Of Prime Rib.This is another eatery that MUST be checked out if you're visiting S.F.The hotel is old and musty. Tommy's for Lunch and The House of Prime Rib CAN NOT BE OVERLOOKED! They ARE the San Francisco experience.House of Prime Rib requires reservations. MAKE THEM... It's worth it!As a person that grew up in SF, I can tell you this, eat at House of Prime Rib and at Tommy's Joynt to experience the TRUE S.F. experience.Here's your plan:1) Stay anywhere you like in S.F.2) Get Lunch at Tommy's Joynt. ( Hand carved Turkey on sourdough + potato salad,+ a good German beer).3) Dinner at House of Prime Rib.After that, you can fool around the city as you please at your own discrecion.Like Pizza? Find Blondies Pizza on Powell near Market St.Have fun in S.F. I hope my restaurant suggestions find you well.I bid you "fair winds and following seas".

Nov 16 2006 	Nothing resembling a Cathedral...	We wound up here because our "booked" hotel had a mishap. They do appear to have started some rennovations - but with the size of this hotel - looks like it could be a long time in the making.

Sep 19 2006 	More than adequate	I first stayed at the Cathedral Hill -- it was then known as the Jack Tar -- nearly 40 years ago. I stayed in it again for two nights this month. The hotel was OK in the 1960s; it's still OK.Rooms are large and well kept. Bathrooms and closets are tiny (as were those in most hotels decades ago), but clean and supplied with the essentials -- including abundant hot water -- as well as an automatic coffee maker. A good-sized television set sits in a large cabinet with three or four large drawers.The Cathedral Hill has a good enough restaurant and a nice bar. On the patio (4th) floor there's a large "Japanese garden" that is a nice place for snacks, drinks, and just lounging about. (Some fourth floor rooms open directly onto the garden, or patio.)The hotel also has a newsstand and other shops. Parking is available; at US$22 a night -- not expensive by San Francisco standards (and the price allows unlimited ins-and-outs).Being at Van Ness and Geary, the Cathedral Hill is not located near San Francisco's main attractions; but the city is small enough that most are within a (somewhat long) walking distance. There are several decent restaurants in the area and Japantown, with the most reasonably priced sushi (and other dishes) in the city, is a five-minute drive away.

On the whole we had a very good Holiday in San Franciscoand would use this Hotel on any future visits.

Apr 21 2006	Great location and price	My husband booked an airfare/hotel package online and this was the hotel he chose. I read these reviews after he booked but before our trip, and I was admittedly nervous. I must say that the hotel exceeded my expectations. The location is fabulous (walking distance to most of the city; bus stop right in front of the hotel) and the lobby/restaurant/gift shop/pool are lovely. We chose to upgrade to a room on the side facing the pool (away from the busy street) and we had a balcony. The wallpaper was unattractive, and the overall decor was dated, but our room was clean and all hotel personnel were helpful and friendly. If you want a great location and price and aren't offended by dated decor, this is the place for you! :)
Mar 28 2006 	No words to describe this dump	Lets put it this way. The less said the better. Motel 6 rates higher. Rooms are incredibly dirty and dumpy.On a scale of 1-10 this hotel rates a -10.

Mar 19 2006 	Not as bad as it sounds-	I stayed here for 3 nights during a conference - read all the reviews on here and got really nervous. If you're looking for a 4-star hotel, don't stay here. But, I didn't have any problems with the hotel. My room was clean, hallways clean, meeting rooms clean, lobby nice and staff nice. So the toilet is hanging from the wall - who the heck cares? It worked every time I flushed it. (I'm short so this didn't bother me, but note that the showerhead is pretty low.) My room was always made up in a timely manner. The concierge was always happy to give directions, call a cab, make suggestions, etc. There is a nice little bar for happy hour and gift shop which always had some sort of fresh fruit and a good selection of sodas, juices, etc. I had breakfast in the hotel - $12 buffet - probably better (& less expensive) across the street at Mel's Diner.All in all, it was a pleasant enough stay. Nothing stellar, but nothing wrong either.

Mar 11 2006	Fair - OK	Stayed 2 nights mid March. Hotel is in a nice area, a bit far from the tourist stuff. As recorded in other reviews the hotel is older. Feb 28 2006	Great price	My husband and I have to say that after reading the reviews posted, we were skeptical and even phoned Priceline with our concerns. Feb 28 2006 	It didn't cost much and it shows	I booked this on Priceline and wasn't very happy when I found I was booked into a hotel in the Tenderloin. Then I came here and read the reviews and I was futher worried.It wasn't quite as bad as feared but it wasn't very good either. Location: right on Van Ness so it wasn't too bad. Just don't walk downhill across Van Ness as it gets ugly fast. Uphill isn't bad. Lots of restaurants around and Whole Foods Market is a 10 minute walk in a safe direction. Heading to Union Square? Take a cab.They don't have a place to park out front while you check in so you have to park in the red zone. Rather annoying.The lobby was very nice. The staff were very friendly. Lots of parking and $20/day isn't bad for San Fran. The better hotels are higher.The room was larger than expected. The carpet was stained like everyone here has stated. The carpets seemed very well worn and the stains seemed old. Even the walls had stains. The maid service missed a crumpled up candy wrapper on the nightstand. The bed was rock hard but the sheets were clean. The bathroom standard and shabby. The tub was small and very dark. The shower head is great if you're under 5 feet tall. The temperature bounced back and forth from hot to cold in the shower every 10 seconds. The toilet looked like something out of a hospital. The sink was old and scratched (one of those shell shaped things). Thin towels.Room service leftovers sat in the hall across from my room the whole day.The elevators were fine and all seemed to work.I was on the side street and it was pretty quiet except for a car alarm early in the morning. It was a Saturday night and I had the windows open all night and no road or people noise.I feel that even though I paid very little for the room by San Fran standards ($65 plus fees/taxes) I feel I overpaid for what I got.

Feb 7 2006	Having Second Thoughts? Dont!	I selected this hotel before I found this site. After reading the reviews I was nervous that I made a mistake and that we would have to stay in the slums of SF. I called the service that I used to book this hotel to try to cancel and they wouldnt allow it. I was prepared to find another hotel and take the loss ($136.00 for 3 nights) after checking out this property.Upon arrival I asked for an upgrade as it was a standard room that I reserved. The woman at the desk was very nice, but there were no upgrades for smoking rooms available. Apparently they had some rain damage and closed of some rooms until it could be repaired. She offered a non-smoking room but I didnt think that I could keep myself from lighting up so I declined.The lobby is very nice and looked like a 4 star hotel lobby. On the way to the elevator I was prepared to find them out of service, but all three were in working condition (I took each one during my stay). They were not creaky or slow. I was beginning to feel better about my stay. When we opened the door to the room (417) I was very surprised. Granted, the room is not a 4 star room (I would have to say 2.5), I was clean and the size of a standard room I am used too. I will have to say that the carpet has seen better days. There were some stains and some cigarette burn marks, but these are things that I am accustomed to seeing in hotels/motels. I could tell that the carpet was vacuumed. The beds were comfortable and the sheets were clean and smelled fresh. The air conditioner did not seem to be powerful, but it did work. There was some mild temperature changes in the shower, but nothing that would burn or freeze you. The toilet had a very powerful flush. There was also a coffee maker, iron, full ironing board and all worked just fine.Once and a while I heard other people talking in their rooms on both sides, but it wasnt anything that kept me from getting any sleep. There were no wild hotel parties, at least not on my floor. There was some street noise, but again, you are in downtown SF.Since we didnt rent a car we took advantage of the tourist desk to get bus information to where we wanted to go. I was so happy that we didnt get a car as everything is just a bus or two away. $1.50 gets you anywhere you want to go by bus. We would usually take a cab back and all the fares were below $10.00 including tip.We didnt eat at the restaurant in the hotel, but walked across the street to Mels Diner for breakfast, and for dinner and drinks (when we didnt feel like going to the clubs) walked across the street to Tommys Joint. The food there is amazing! Everything was far less expensive then I had expected. Dinner there was always under $20 for two. I cannot say how much the food there is to die for.Ok, now for a summary of this property. I would not recommend this hotel for anyone on a honeymoon or anything like that. This is an excellent place for a tourist who will only be sleeping and showering at night, and exploring this great city during the day. For price, I do not think that I would pay more then $90 a night. Location is the key here. Dont rent a car if you plan on staying in the city. If you plan on going to the wine areas I would recommend renting a car at the hotel for the day when you want to go. DO wear comfortable shoes! DONT take all of the negative reviews as fact. I have posted pictures here as well so you can make your own decision. I would definitely stay here again.If you have any questions, please feel free to email me!

Jan 29 2006	Fine for short stay	Stayed for two nights with a Tour group. Rooms tidy and clean although our aircon wouldn't turn off. Good cinema across the street and a few places to eat around the hotel if you don't want to eat in the hotel. Good bus links down to Union Square.

Jan 4 2006	No recommendation here	I booked this hotel online before I knew about Trip Advisor (can't remember which site I used). Dec 21 2005 	It's seen better times ...	The Cathedral Hill has seen better times. What makes this hotel attractive is the fact you can find very low rates. I paid $75 night WITH parking! That is cheap for SF. But, despite the low price and to me great location (I enjoy Polk St., all the Thai restaurants, and other great hole in walls) I doubt I'll stay there again and pay the extra money to stay somewhere else. I stayed there for 4 days including the weekend. This was my second stay so, I requested to be on the garden view side ... not much of a view but, very quiet since you are not facing Van Ness. But, given the low price, the Cathedral Hill as become known to locals as the "Go-tel." On both Friday and Saturday night, once I stepped out of the elevator, I felt I walked into one of the Adult nightspots such as Mitchell Bros or New Century which are a few blocks down from the hotel. Let's just say lots of loud "adult" sounds (not the TV) and just hope you don't have a child with you. In addition, many parties were going on in the rooms too. In fact, on my floor security had to clear out two rooms due to a fight breaking out. Apparently, both rooms were filled with teenagers; drinking and doing drugs.During the workweek, the hotel was not as booked and it was more quiet overall. Being an ex-resident of San Francisco, I go back several years on business. From what I was told on this visit when meeting with local friends, the site where the hotel sits is going to be turned into a hospital. If true, that explains why the carpet is terrible, the decor is very outdated, and the bathroom is something to laugh at. I am very tall and the shower head did not reach the middle of my chest. I had to do yoga-like moves in order to wash my face and hair. The TV is terrible with a half-dozen channels. The room was pretty much the same as my last stay almost a year ago but, again, I was attracted by the price and figured I'd give it a second try.In fairness, this is what you get for the price being so inexpensive. The staff was very nice and they do accomadate. No issue with the staff. Although many here have issue with the area, that is secondary to me. I actually like the area as it is as real as SF gets but, when in a hotel I want to feel like I've escaped the outside elements; not bring them inside with me. I want to be able to walk into a room and kick my shoes off; not feel I have to keep them on because the carpet is so dirty. I want variety on the TV if relaxing ... I want quietness ... I want a clean functionable bathroom ... I don't want to hear what others are doing in their rooms. It's those reasons why I won't stay there again regardless of price. As mentioned, location is about as urban as SF gets. You do have to cross the Tenderloin to get to downtown. A walk to downtown shopping and the theater district is 15 minutes. So, you will see all the negative elements that SF has to offer (homeless, prostitutes, drug addicts, panhandlers). Polk St. is just one block down which has a mix of everything. The immediate area has everything from cheap good restaurants, small bars, clubs (straight, gay, and transgender), shops, coffee houses, as well as adult entertainment. City Hall as well as the Opera House are close by. Basically, everything is walkable. I say a great location if a single traveler, boyfriend/girlfriend traveler, clubber, nightowl, bar hopper, or couple with no kids who are on an adventure. Not recommended if you are a family with children or a business traveler who desires a quiet area and expect "business" style or "executive" accomadations.

Dec 2 2005	Not Great Not Bad...	I never thought I'd write a review of a hotel before, but here I am doing just that! As stated in other reviews, the elevator from the garage was out of commission, so we used a SERVICE ELEVATOR...very nasty! Once inside the hotel, it wasn't so bad. Nov 22 2005	Not up to standards	We transferred to this hotel because the hotel we where staying at was booked for the weekend. There's a reason this hotel has plenty of availability. Oct 11 2005	Not the Plaza but not too bad.	After reading some of the reviews on this hotel I was a bit worried. I was traveling with my husband and 8-month old son and was concerned about the cleanliness of the room. Check in was a breeze ... parking was very convenient ($20 extra per day) - right below the hotel. There is very low clearance, though. We were in a Sequoia and it barely cleared. We opened the sunroof and could touch the ceiling with our hands. Parking stalls are also pretty narrow. We were on the 8th floor in a very clean, very quiet room. Of course, it was fleet week and the Blue Angels were performing. That was the only noise we heard, though. TV's had the general cable channels as well as Starz. Pay-per-view movies and games were available. Complimentary (small) bottles of wine were in the room too ... a red and a white.The bathroom is small and the shower is VERY dark once you close the shower curtain. There were nice towels and bathrobes to use. Also, there was a nice vanity mirror with a light for make up. We didn't eat at the restaurants, but probably would have had we not had existing dining plans with family and friends. There is a small espresso/pastry shop in the lobby, a bistro/grill restaurant (menu looked great) and then a more casual breakfast buffet area. There is a 24-hr Mel's Diner across the street. I was tempted to go grab some pancakes when my son woke up at 3 am :). There is also a pastry/donut/coffee shop across the street. There is an area to sign up for tours, etc. or general directions in the city and there is a small store for essentials and souvenirs. I met some friends for dinner that night and the hotel graciously called a taxi for me, escorted me out to the pick up area and told the driver where I was headed. Overall I think the staff was awesome and the accommodations were nicer than your typical Ramada/Best Western, etc., but not quite as nice as Westins/Hyatts. Of course, there could be nicer/larger rooms in this hotel ... we just pricelined it and booked the smallest one. As for the location, it is several blocks ($7 cab ride) to Union Square and a little bit further to the restaurants in North Beach. It worked well for our purposes, though, of visiting friends in different areas of the city.Check-out was just as smooth. We were on our way in about two minutes. All in all, not a bad experience at all. Nice lobby, nice staff and a clean room are exactly what I need in a hotel.

Sep 11 2005 	A Priceline disaster	I'm a frequent visitor to San Francisco, and have used Priceline on a number of occasions to find rooms. I've generally bid on a "four-star" room, and have ended up in such typical business hotels as the Hilton and the Holiday Inn in the Financial District. My one bid on a "three-star" put me in the Pickwick, which turned out to be a decent enough experience. I turned to Priceline over Labor Day weekend after I discovered that my favorite "budget" hotel, the Castle Inn, could not accommodate me. I was unable to get a "four-star" or a "boutique" room on my latest attempt, and my offer of $72 a night for a "three-star" was finally accepted. When I was given the name of the hotel, I read the reviews here, and although I was taken aback by what I read, I hoped for the best.Unfortunately, the general consensus on the place turned out to be correct. I arrived at about midnight, and even though Priceline had guaranteed a late arrival, the desk clerk made a snide comment about my arrival time. The king room I requested was not available, and she claimed that the only room left in the hotel was a queen. She assured me, however, that I would be getting a non-smoking room, and I decided to reserve further judgment until I got upstairs.I knew I would be disappointed as I walked down the hall to the room--the wallpaper was marked and dirty, and the paint on the doors was marred and chipped. When I arrived at my room (659), I was greeted by a broken switchplate and the odors of both mildew and cigarette smoke. The lights came on to reveal cheap, scratched furniture with cigarette burns, worn and dirty carpet that was well overdue for replacement, and a rock-hard bed with a worn bedspread. The tub had rust stains, and the vanity was stratched and burned as well. The ventilation system was literally decades old, and during my entire four-day stay, I could not get any airflow in the room.The service was no better. Both the night and the morning desk clerks insisted that no other rooms were available, and since I was preoccupied with business matters, I eventually gave up and resigned myself to staying in the room. For two of the four nights there, I received no linen service, and my call to housekeeping went unanswered. Garage parking was $23 per night, including tax, which was well in keeping with prices throughout the city.I realize that $72 isn't a lot of money for a hotel room in SF, and I don't have a problem staying in budget accommodations. However, I do have a problem with the place being advertised as a "three-star" establishment, which, according to both Priceline and AAA, is one that offers special amenities. Quite simply, the hotel is in desperate need of renovation (both the physical plant and the front office), and unless you have no other option, I would give it a wide berth.

Aug 15 2005	It could have been worse....	Okay, I read the other reviews so I wasn't expecting plush accomodations, but the room I got was small and NOISY! Thank goodness the weather was very cool. The room itself was kept spotless by housekeeping, but the furnishings were very old and Motel 6ish. Room lighting left a lot to be desired. Three lamps but all with those fluorescent bulb inserts that combined with the yellowed lampshades made me feel like I had hepatitis everytime I looked into the mirror. The beds were reasonable good, but the blankets were old and pilled and the sheets had holes in them. The pillows were just plain awful. Put the rooms on the 7th floor on the fast track for renovation! The garage below the hotel was convenient, but very crowded and tight to get in and out. The restaurant on the other hand had a pretty good breakfast buffet daily for $12.

Feb 1 2005	This Place is FINE. Not a 5-star hotel but passable for those on a budget!	listen, i did the priceline thing and ended up trying to save some cashola and put in my price per night for a hotel: $65 and ended up with being given the cathedral hill hotel. it's not as bad as many of these reviews make it out to be. perhaps they paid well over $100 per night. i wouldn't do that, but $65 a night, pretty much with a good location (center of san francisco) and ease to walk to BART, MUNI is all over, close to the 101N approach to the Golden Gate Bridge and just as close to 101S/280, it's a good overall location. Nov 16 2009 	WORST HOTEL I HAVE EVER STAYED AT - Rude staff and Management	I would not recommend staying at the Clift. The common areas including the Redwood bar are beautiful so its a great spot as far as night life. I checked into one of their one bedroom suites on a Saturday evening. The room itself was generous in size but the bathroom was quite small and there was no half bath in living room of suite. None of that, however, was my problem with the hotel. My experience About half an hour after checking in I attempted to call down to room service and request a buck of ice. However, neither of the phones in the suite worked. This was not a huge deal so I picked up my cell phone and called the main reception line to request the bucket of ice. The hotel receptionist asked what room I was in and what the name on the account was. When I replied she told me that was not the name on the account and I would have to provide her with the correct account information before she could help me with my request. I explained that unfortunately I could not tell her what surname she was showing in the computer but I was most definitely checked in that room. This went in circles several times before she hung up on me. Thoroughly frustrated I left the room and took the elevator downstairs to speak with the manager on duty. He apologized and said that he would speak with the receptionist as well as send up a bucket of ice and maintenance to fix the phone. Perfect. About, fifteen minutes later someone came to fix the phone. Thirty minutes after that my bucket of ice still had not arrived and I had to call room service again. When the bucket of ice arrived it was two hours after I initially picked up the phone to request it. Later that evening my girlfriend and I returned to the suite with two friends. Less than ten minutes later there was a knock on the door from two large security guards that our neighbor was complaining about the music. The music was on very low and it was a Saturday night but not looking argue we turned the radio off all together and continued our conversation. At this point the same individuals in the next room begin banging furniture around and hitting the walls. I called down to the front desk to complain and as far as I can tell no one ever spoke them as this continued for ten or fifteen minutes. At this point there is a knock on our door again, the same two securities guards plus the female night manager. She informs us that now we are talking too loud and that she could hear our conversation from the elevator bank. I explain to her that is impossible that she head us talking, at a normal tone, all the way from the elevators and ask if they ever sent someone to speak with our noisy neighbors. She dodged the question and continues that we are being unruly and she would have to ask the two guests not staying at the hotel to leave. I explained to her that we were very much in our rights as hotel guest to hold a conversation within our room. She refused to see my point of view or accommodate us in any way, by moving the other guest or us. At this point, thoroughly frustrated, I told her that if this was how the Clift hotel treated its guests we would be leaving, to which she replied fine. We called American Express back and luckily they were able to find us a hotel nearby, the Palace, that was much more accommodating despite the late hour.Upon checking out I spoke to the same manager again. I tried to rationalized with her that it was quite ridiculous to expect a hotel guest not to speak in their own room. She explained that the walls were thin and it probably had to do but the door adjoining our suite to the neighboring room. I cannot understand how it is the guests issue that the hotel is not properly sound proofed. I also asked her why she did not make an attempt to move either us or the next room over, before taking the extreme action of asking people to leave. She told me the hotel was fully booked. I find this hard to believe as I cannot see how we received an upgrade in a fully booked hotel.In all my years of traveling I have never been treated so poorly by a hotel. I never received any follow up from management apologizing or trying to deal with the situation. I called and spoke to one manager directly and although she apologetic for the situation she would not apologize for the way we were treated or the managers actions.

The bed was the hardest I've ever slept on, and needless to say we didn't get much sleep each night. Room service - I'm still in shock over how expensive breakfast was one morning. Coffee for 2, OJ, 3 scrambled eggs, granola and yogart, and a breakfast burrito = $80.00. Not kidding. I'd highly recommend getting up and walking a block to a restaurant. We ate at the hotel restaurant, Asia De Cuba on Sunday night and the food/service was fantastic. Same menu as the one in New York. A bit too pricy for some people, but hey it's vacation! One thing we didn't know was that the lobby bar turns into a club on the weekends. It's apparently "the place to be" and is extremely crowded. We're by no means fuddy duddys and like to go out to clubs once in a while. But having a club where you sleep isn't the best scenario. Every time we tried to walk back into the hotel at the end of the night, we were stopped by the stereotypical LA/NYC rude doorman until he was convinced we weren't trying to sneak into the bar. I would not stay here again because it's not worth the money. And who wants to fight their way past a snotty doorman and a crowd of people to get to the too-small room with a very hard bed.

Sep 5 2009 	Calm and relaxing hotel with great design	I had a deluxe room on the 12th floor and found the accommodation to be excellent. My room was beautifully designed, large, comfortable and with a nice view. The bathrooms are pretty small but I dont spend too much time there and prefer to have more space in the room itself.I liked the closets with space to get all your stuff out of the room and maintain the clean design.I was a bit frustrated by the high charge for wifi but this practice is pretty much universal across all hotels that I've stayed in.... I guess no one forced me to use it.The staff were amiable and helpful when needed. I prefer the less is more style of service in hotels and dont like over attentive staff (this might be an English thing) but for me the staff found the right tone and the right level of service.I would definitely stay here again although its worth hunting around for a good rate on a deluxe room if possible.

Sep 4 2009 	So much style - but not in bathrooms and service	The rooms/suites of the clift, just as the lobby and the bar are state of the art STYLE.The bathrooms of the hotelrooms though are beyound motel standard - I mean it...All the service staff is extremly good looking, extremly bored and extremly far away from any 5 star hotel service.Still, especially if you travel on your own: the redwood bar is the place to be..locals register weeks upfront to be left in, all are around 25-45, attractive and extremly dressed-up, even on week days.Hotel Rates sometimes go up to 300$..check with your local travel agency - I usually never do that, but it turns out, the clift has very good rates with some travel agencies (in germany with TUI and Neckarman, we stayed in a suite for 180$, which is very decent.)

Sep 1 2009	Fantastic hotel	We stayed at the Clift Hotel for 5 days and enjoyed every minute of it. Check in was quick and easy and the rooms are very spacious. The bathroom is a little small and outdated, but otherwise fine. The reception desk and the concierge were always friendly, though sometimes a bit slow in making reservations for restaurants etc. All in all I would definitely stay here again. The location is great as you can walk to the major attractions.

Aug 31 2009 	Bad customer service	We were happy with the hotel until we found out that our credit card had been charged for $340 for a mini bar we had apparently cleaned out. This was not the case since we never even opened the minibar during our stay which lasted only from 11PM to 8AM. When we went to speak with the manager, we were made to wait in the hall for a long time and when the manager finally spoke with us, he did so in front of a lobby full of people and in a manner that was rude and defensive. Finally, we got our money back, but I would definitely not stay there in the future nor recommend the hotel.

Aug 24 2009 	NEGATIVE NEGATIVE NEGATIVE	The hotel is old with just a fresh coat of paint...the walls are SUPER thin (lets just say we knew EVERYTHING the neighbors were doing..) plus we could hear the base from club downstairs until 2-3AM...the bathrooms are impossibly small and being 8 months pregnant did not make it any easier! Aug 20 2009 	Great public spaces but average rooms	The other reports on here are fairly accurate. Food was good in the asia de cuba restaurants, and the cocktails were delicious in the redwood rooms.Overall a decent city hotel

Aug 17 2009 	An updated funky old hotel with very thin walls	My husband and I stayed at the Clift Hotel for the 4th of July. We were really excited about it because we were able to get a great rate through Expedia. The hotel is really interesting - very hip, funky decor, but it is very apparent that the bones of the hotel are really old. They have done a successful job of updating the look and feel of the rooms with minimalist decor, but certain elements - such as the bathrooms and the dark hallways that would look really depressing if they weren't painted lavender - date the building. The location - right by Union Square is perfect for exploring San Francisco. The best part of our stay was having such a fun bar in the hotel after returning from Hubert Keller's awesome restaurant, Flur de lys. The worst part - the walls of our room were VERY thin and our neighbors were having a very good time next door...

Aug 16 2009 	not impressed	dark hotel is very much yesterday in my opinion.Crazy prices, homeless people seem to surround the hotel which can be daunting.We were evacuated from the hotel at 5am for a fire alarm. This whole dark image inside gets boring quite quickly as do the silly prices for basic items..

Aug 16 2009 	Good but not Great	Well located hip hotel with good rooms but not great bathrooms. Strangely there is no art on the walls and therefore rooms can feel quite sparse/cold. Be aware the hotel is big and therefore the customer service is not as good as it could be  no one helped with our baggage on both our stays and you feel like you are being processed through as opposed to being really looked after.

Aug 13 2009 	Beautifully appointed wonderfully staffed	This is a gorgeous hotel. The staff is excellent, with some of the nicest, courteous and most professional people that I have encountered in a long while. The decorations in my room were beautiful! Also, the lobby is out of this world, with an over sized chair and fireplace that are very fun and inviting. The hotel boasts a great club/lounge/restaurant that seems to have all the beautiful people in San Francisco grace it's doors.One quibble however. Housekeeping knocks on doors at 8 am. You can hear them in the hallway knocking away until they make it to your room. I had to request that they not knock before 10 am. But that is a small gripe for such a wonderful hotel.

Aug 11 2009 	Right in the center of the action	We stayed at the Clift for one night on a Travelzoo promotion - double upgrade to a suite for $145/night. We were pretty happy with the room, especially at that price, but if I paid $350 per night like they supposedly used to charge, I would be pretty unhappy. The room had absolutely no view, but we didn't really care. The lobby is very dark, so much so that it took awhile for our eyes to adjust before we could see anything. The staff was okay but we have certainly seen better service at other hotels. For example, our group of seven wanted a drink and there was no room at the bar - which is quite busy late at night, by the way - so we asked if we could buy drinks and drink them in a non-busy area of the lobby that had enough seating for our group. They wouldn't let us do it, and there was no explanation as to why we couldn't. Well, they lost out on about $150 for no good reason, which we ended up spending at the St. Francis down the street. Other than that little issue, we had a nice time and the hotel is centrally located close to theaters and restaurants.

Aug 10 2009 	Overpriced and Underpar	I must say, when I looked at the Clift's website I was excited about staying at this hotel...My husband and I are from the east coast and took a month vacation/business trip to the west coast. We are used to staying in the top rated hotels; San Francisco was our last stop after visiting Sedona AZ, Las Vegas, and Napa Valley.Upon arrival at the Clift, we waited almost 10 minutes for someone to valet our car, and while waiting we were approached by 3 homeless people. Once we got to our room, it was not what we had expected. The room was extremely small, just enought room for a bed and a very small desk; the bathroom was a nightmare, there was barely enough room for one person and I nearly broke my neck getting into the shower because they use some sort of shiner on the tub that makes it very slippery. As an avid traveler I often expect city hotel rooms to be on the smaller side but this room was ridiculous, there was barely room to put our luggage. However I will sazy that the room was very n icely decorated.The hotel was ridiculously expensive (I paid $6.50 for a soda at the bar). We paid $57 a day to park our car when we realized the day we left that theere was a parking garage 2 blocks aaway that charged $19 a day.Now I could have dealt with the small room and the overpriced food and drinks but the service waas among the worst service I have ever had in my life! The bellhop ran right into me with his giant cart, and cut open my ankle, and then HE looked at ME like I did something wrong (he never even apologized even after my husband said something to him). The "doormen" don't open the doors for you, they stand around outside chatting amongst themselves. Everyone was rude from the valet, to the front desk, to the waitstaff at their restaurant. The most polite people were the maid staff, even though we had to call down each day to have our room cleaned.I would not recommend this hotel to anyone... Other than its location, this hotel has nothing to offer; there are a lot of options in this city and The Clift would not be in my top 10 for first choices. Save yourself the money and dissapointment because you could probably find better service at a Holiday Inn.

Aug 9 2009	Do NOT even contemplate staying here	Complete rip off and over priced. The attitude is a very affected 'style over content' - but unfortunately the style is terribly dated, despite its claims to be avant garde (sorry Philippe Starck, this isn't one of your better examples). When enquiries are made to staff about the distinct lack of necessary items in rooms, they lazily cite the 'minimalist design' as the reason. At these prices, and when staying for the best part of a week, I don't think expecting to find furniture into which clothes can be stored is too much to ask.I've seen bigger bathrooms on airplanes. No mixer, so the entire duration of every shower was spent adjusting the ever-changing water temperature.House keeping was inconsistent and unattentive.This is was the worst kind of hotel stay - I spent lots of money and did not get the value of it in return.

Aug 7 2009 	I would be very annoyed if I had paid more	We stayed ar rhis hotel to take advantage of a travelzoo promotion that gave us a deluxe king room for $145. The corner room we had was attractive, in a self-concious post-modernistic way, but it was very noisy. I cannot understand why it apparently did not occur to the interior designer that hotel guests might like to have furniture that included drawers or at least a closet with reasonably-sized shelves and perhaps might need a place in the bathroom to put things. What really annoyed me, however, was the list of items in the room that were for sale at ridiculous prices, including $3 for a sewing kit of the sort that is distributed for free at many low end hotels/motels and $150 for a shower robe that was comparable to ones they have at CostCo for $30. And let's not forget the liter of water for $11. If there is a similar deal available on my next trip to San Francisco, I would consider returning to the Clift for the location, but would prefer to stay elsewhere.

Aug 6 2009 	OK Hotel the rooms are extremely loud....	Stayed for a night in late June. Had an amzing rate through hotwire so booked it. The lobby and bar and lounge are really warm and cozy. The best part of the hotel. The service was fine, most of the employees were young and it seemed that they were new hires trying hard but learning the ropes. The rooms were plain white, the lighting was fair at best, walls paper thin. We could hear our next door neighbors convo at they were not speaking loudly. The bathrooms were tiny, toiletries were missing and one towel in the bathroom. The beds were very comfy and the sheets were of high thread count. Hard to believe this hotel was charging plus $350 a year or 2 ago. The hotel was next to empty and I would imagine the economy played a huge factor in that. The place just felt a little off and had this cold and dark feeling. Not what I expected.

Aug 4 2009 	One of the best hotel I have ever stayed in!	Wow! Our trip started out great. We had an early arrival and checked-in around 10 am. The lady at the reception desk was friendly and enjoyable. We got a great rate on the room $145/night with a double-upgrade). Our room was ready when we arrived and once we walked into our room we were so impressed. We had a corner suite with a huge room, nice vanity sitting area and nice bathroom. As with the older, more historic hotels the bathrooms are usually small. Our bathroom was a decent size (nothing to complain about). We utilized the concierge on a few occasions - restaurant reservations and for tour ideas. They were phenomenal! Great service, great suggestions and we got a wonderful table at Ozumo. We were able to get a table overlooking the bay for the same evening they made our reservations (the restaurant was packed). We cannot stop raving about our stay at Clift and the spectacular service we received when staying there. We would not have a problem paying full price for our next trip out there (oops, maybe I shouldn't say that). The convenience of having a car service at our disposal 24/7 was much appreciated and well utilized. I cannot stop raving about our trip out to San Francisco and the Clift Hotel had a big part in making this such a phenominal trip!

Aug 1 2009 	The Clift is a level above all the rest in every aspect and cannot be missed if you want to feel like royalty.	Check in to check out, the Clift provided a feeling hospitality and a level of service rarely experienced. Our stay was as enjoyable as we've ever experienced. David, Stacey, Scott and Dan Lewis were extraordinary. The concierge services were outstanding, food and beverage likewise followed (dinner and breakfasts at their restaruant Asia de Cuba,) and where else does a bellman (Scott) remember and address you by name? We'll return and when in Miami or SF our choice will be a Morgan property. Again, our thanks for a great four days!

Jul 31 2009 	Jaw-Droppingly Amazing	There really are no words to express how amazing my stay at The Clift was. Upon deciding to take a last-minute trip to San Francisco, I priced a variety of hotels looking for the best option. I have stayed at a number of different hotels in the greater Union Square area, usually switching off between The Clift, Westin St. Francis, Westin Market Street, or W. I've always been a fan of The Clift, and admire the tasteful decor, and how it truly is a very boutique property (very unique design, yet still functional and fun). Upon checking rates, I found a great price via Hotels.com for The Clift, and decided to book it for two nights.I took the BART into San Francisco from the East Bay, and walked the short distance from the Powell Street station to The Clift hotel. The area is wonderful; located just off of Union Square (roughly two blocks), you pass some interesting art galleries, restaurants, and shops. There are some delicious restaurants within walking distance, and a very conveniently located Walgreens and Starbucks within about 100 meters of the hotel. Check-in was fast and easy; the nice girl at the counter recognized me as a guest who had been to the hotel before, and inquired how things (job, for example), was going. I very much enjoyed the personal touch. The girl kindly upgraded me to a larger room, and asked if I would need any assistance with my luggage.My room was beautiful! Amazing bed (truly one of the most comfortable, more-so than the W's Heavenly Bed), and a very functional workspace. The room was spacious by any standards, especially San Francisco standards, and for two-three people, I never found it cramped in any way. The room included a nicely stocked mini-bar with snacks (not obscenely overpriced, though the Walgreens across the street made it nice to go for a short walk and pick up bottles of water and snacks and not pay hotel prices. Like just about every San Francisco hotel, wireless internet was available for a fee, but I had no hesitations about paying when needing to do work. Overall, i found the room to be very comfortable for sleeping, working, and entertaining, though the property was inviting and made me want to explore common areas.While I did not dine at the Asia De Cuba restaurant for dinner, my brother and I took advantage of visiting the Redwood Room for dessert. The bar/lounge was packed for a Sunday night, and upon asking the hostess for a table, she checked to verify we were guests, and asked us to wait a moment. WIthin a minute, she had asked two patrons to vacate the table they were using, put a reserved sign on it, and had us sit down. A very nice touch, as it's wonderful to know guests of the property are treated like VIPs within their own hotel. Neither of us drink alcohol, but we ordered some iced tea, water, a snack, and dessert. We had a fun time chatting with the hostess and people-watching, and the food was delicious. The bill was very reasonable, and even after leaving around midnight, the lounge was still packed with people coming in.The next morning, we opted to eat in the hotel at the Asia De Cuba restaurant. There was a nice buffet setup, and the waiter was very prompt and precise. The restaurant was not entirely crowded (it was roughly around 10:00am), and even for the late breakfast hour, there were still plenty of choices available. We walked around the property and enjoyed making use of the fitness center (VERY tasteful and functional, especially for free), as well as the little nooks the lobby has to offer. Other things of interest were the kind and helpful concierge, who might as well have been a robot; he knew answers to questions that most people would have to Google (what time random art galleries open and close, quickest routes to places), and the hotel offers a very prompt and elegant car service for $15 (we took the car to North Beach).Overall, The Clift is certainly a great property for just about any occasion. I would opt to stay here over anywhere else, including the W (not very personalized service) or much more expensive places like the Four Seasons or Ritz Carlton (maybe it's just my taste, but I find them INCREDIBLY overpriced for what they offer). The greatest touch The Clift offered was the kind staff; everyone was welcoming and wanted to engage in conversation. I truly feel as if I made friends at the property, and felt nice when my name was remembered, even to people I had only met briefly.I highly recommend this property for any occasion (business, leisure, romantic getaway, or just a nice night out), and truly do not see how anyone could be disappointed.

Jul 27 2009 	Very Cool Hotel but Not Luxurious	I have been a regular visitor to the bar and restaurant at this hotel for many years, back when I used to live in the Bay Area. Recently I booked a 1 year anniversary trip with my wife and decided to stay here. We had some sort of large suite that was very spacious, but very sparse. The bed was not exceedingly comfortable, but wasn't bad either. The rooms are edgy but cold. The bathroom was huge but felt like a hospital and had a serious issue with the water from the shower ending up in the hallway.The lobby is fantastic and the Redwood Room Bar and Asia De Cuba restaurant are some of the cooler spots in the entire city. We returned nightly to long lines of people waiting to get past the ropes into the bar, but the staff remembered us by sight and let us through quickly with a pleasant hello. Most staff remembered our names even though we were only here for 4 days. The staff were as good as any Four Seasons or Peninsula. Surprisingly the incredibly loud bar scene of the lobby did not make it to our room on the 5th floor. Street noise, however, had no problem at all getting into our room at all times and woke us up every morning. The location is excellent.Ultimately the hotel will guarantee a pleasant and exciting stay- but not a quiet and luxurious one. Like most Ian Schrager properties (hotel owner) the aim is for a Cool, Hip, Edgy feeling, not pampering. The staff are great though- no edge at all just awesome service. We knew what we were getting into and liked it. Probably would have been more appropriate for another type of trip, rather than a 1 year anniversayr because "romantic" doesn't come to mind- but we had a great time anyway.No spa onsite. We went to the Ritz for that.

Jul 21 2009 	The good the bad and the ugly.	We chose The Clift because it looked fun and unique from it's web site. It is unique in decor with some hits and some misses. Modern and funky, but honestly it just felt like we were sleeping in a nightclub. The bar downstairs is very popular, but unfortunately not my scene. If you are in your 20-30's, VERY SINGLE, and hoping to score you would like this place. They have some serious house music playing all night on Fridays and Saturdays, but to their credit it wasn't too noisy in my room on the sixth floor. I could still hear it, but it wasn't terrible. Room- modern decor. Lots of mirrors to try and make the room appear larger. The bed basically took up the whole room. The bed was awesome and I slept like a baby. Big plus. The big minus was that my husband and I had to take turns walking around the room cause navigating around the bed was a bit of a challenge. Another big minus was that the shower did not drain properly. Called the front desk within the first hour upon checking in. They immediately sent someone to look at it. After a draino job later, it worked a bit better but still drained very slowly and I pretty much always had an inch of water in the tub while I showered.Service- the staff were all lovely and very attentive. No complaints there at all.Location- pretty good as far as daylight was concerned. Lots of stuff right around the hotel. Walgreens, bagel shop, cute diners, easy walk into Union Sq. At night, it gets a bit sketchy. Lots of homeless people in that particular area, as well as lots of people looking to party. Do not walk around that area at night alone. I live in Boston, and also lived in NYC, and I was definitely a little worried after 11pm hit. Dining Tips: We are foodies and went to many great restaurants while we were there visiting friends. Check out Town Hall for good Southern inspired cuisine. So yummy! The bbq shrimp app was AMAZING. We all wanted to lick the plate. Brenda's is an awesome little French/Cajun place that serves up one of the best breakfasts I've ever feasted on. Apparently it is next to impossible to get in on a weekend brunch, so I recommend going for bfast during a workday morning. Only maybe 10 tables in the whole place. Really fantastic food. Do not miss out on trying the beignet flight! They are like donuts and filled with goodness. I will be craving them for weeks to come!

Jul 16 2009 	Like kids again	We dropped our two children off with grandma & grandpa, then headed for a weekend getaway in our own city. We checked into the Clift, and were promptly taken care of. The studio room was excellent. We enjoyed the well decorated lobbies, and the Redwood Room was a load of fun. The location of the hotel was great. Close to the Fillmore theatre, where the Mighty Mighty Bosstones played. Walked from the Hotel throughout Union Square, China town, North Beach, Fisherman's wharf & back. Loved it.

Jul 15 2009 	Excellent Staff	We are two older couples that booked the Clift Hotel for the Friends and Family Rate. After reading the reviews, we expected a trendy, dark, noisy, small room boutique hotel. We did find a dark, trendy, boutique hotel with a great location and an excellent, friendly, helpful staff. The room was small but it is a downtown hotel in an older building. Our biggest complaint was having no where to unpack our clothes. We lived out of our suitcases for five nights. The bathroom was adequate with hangers on the door for our toiletries and a couple of shelves above the commode. The bed and comforter were luxurious. We were not bothered by any street or hallway noise. The gym was outstanding. We are not into the bar scene but did go in the lounge on Sunday night for a drink $$$$. Service was excellent and our server was very friendly. The desk staff, door staff, and concierge were most helpful. I can't praise them enough.

Jul 14 2009 	Fun hotel great bar friendly/attentive staff	I booked a last minute stay and got a great rate. I was able to upgrade upon checking in to a quite large room. This hotel has a great location, excellent restaurant and a can't-be-missed bar. Though one of the trendier hotels in SF, all of the staff I dealt with were extremely friendly and helpful (unlike at other trendy hotels). The only downside is a smallish (though nicely furnished) bathroom which is part of the "charm" of a vintage property.

Jul 9 2009 	Awesome Centrally Located Beautiful People Great Concierge	I'm 43 yrs old and visited the Clift SF from NYC on July 4th weekend with my girlfriend. To give context for our preferences, we typically hang in the East Village and Lower East Side in Manhattan, and enjoy drinks and appetizers rather than heavy meals that make you feel fat and tired. The Clift was excellent. Clift is a "cool" (some would say trendy) luxury hotel where many good-looking people hang. The hotel is dimly lighted. Some reviews did not like that, but it did not bother me at all (akin to Paramount or Royalton in NYC). Clift is downtown and centrally located. Clift staff suggested not renting a car for the entire stay - I agree. We walked the entire city over the weekend and then rented a car from the Clift on Monday returning it at SFO after driving to Napa and the Cliff Hotel on the Pacific. We stayed in the Deluxe King at $215 per night - an excellent rate for a spacious clean room with a nice view. Elevators were fast, room was clean, service was excellent. Stock your refrig with goods from Walgreens across the street. Uncrowded Starbucks also across the street. Staff was friendly helpful, not overbearing. I recommend you call the concierge and tell them exactly what you want to see - they are very knowledgeable and will direct you to the best places. Don't get too caught up with maps and guides, just call the concierge. Be specific. If you want to see something "funky" don't be embarrassed just say what you want and the concierge will get you there. We did and had a blast. Our weekend was basically walking around everywhere (Pacific Heights, North Beach, Castro, Mission, Filmore Street, Haight Ashbury etc.) laughing all the way, and tasting cool foods and many drinks - a martini at the Top of the Mark Hotel and a double Mojito in Sausalito (by ferry) were particularly hilarious. I'd skip Fisherman's Wharf (akin to NYC Southstreet seaport and China Town ("the original" but seems the same in every city I visit), unless you are into that sort of thing. We enjoyed Napa but the ride is a bit long and honestly we preferred checking out the city sites and people. This may be shallow, but wineries all seem the same to me. Check our Muir Woods if you like HUGE trees.If you have 5% of the good time I had, you will be extremely satisfied. Good luck.

Jul 7 2009 	Excellent location view and amenities	The Clift combines a sweeping view, a prime location and a unique charm that makes it a winner.Just two blocks off Union Square, this property manages to meld Old World high-end seclusion with modern chic sensibilities. Colored-mirrored elevators combine with stalely redwood-paneled lobby decor for a decadent, yet playful effect.The rooms are spacious and bright, with grand views of the city. Enormous mirrors and firm beds made the room a pleasure. Windows open to allow the city's breeze to cool you into a deep, relaxing sleep.The amenities are endless, from concierge services to an extremely well-stocked minibar.This is a hotel for the person who enjoys luxury, but enjoys it with a modern twist.

Jul 4 2009 	An Alright Hotel	An overall very nice hotel. Very modern feel on the inside and the old world charm of a heritage building on the outside. Close to all the major shopping and theatres. My only complaint is the the windows and walls didn't do much for sound. You could here everything outside and in the hallways while in your room. But if you looking for a nice place to stay in the heart of San Fran I would recommend this hotel.

Jul 2 2009 	Beware...What a dissappointment	We had reservations for 4 nights and we checked out at 6:15 am following the first nights stay. The sink takes up a fourth of the total bathroom sq. footage. Hotel does not have a ice machine and charges for internet connection. Upon check-out and after I had expressed my discontent, the clerk informed me that there would be a $50.00 early departure fee. After a brief discussion the fee was waived. The location of the hotel is accommodating. Strongly recommend staying elsewhere.

Jul 1 2009 	Fabulously cool and serene place to enjoy a HOT town!	Partner and I stayed at Clift for Gay Pride. We also helped set up host a Hospitality Suite for our organization. Partner is disabled and the staff went out of their way at every turn to meet her needs. Everyone was fun and friendly; Eric Shangle made our group feel very welcome! and location was a nice walking distance from Pride events. Even spotted a few celebrities in the hotel! LOVED IT!

Thank you, Clift Hotel, for a wonderful experience and a fantastic weekend!

Jun 29 2009	Best travel experience i've had in a long time	Everyone at this hotel was simply amazing throughout the entire weekend at meeting our needs and ensuring we were well taken care of. Eric Shangle was our contact and helped us set everything up and was there for us throughout the weekend if we needed anything and helped us tie up some loose ends even after we left the hotel on Monday. I will definitely stay at the Clift when I go back to San Francisco.

Jun 25 2009 	Can a hotel be any darker?	The Clift Hotel was announced as one with a special design interior. And this was the case. Any daylight was taken out of the lobby, the bar, the restaurant etc...The first floor has the feel of a dungeon. Not what we were looking for if you come to discover San Francisco for a couple of days.Upon arrival the first thing I noticed is that there wasn't any form of roof or arching under which our cab could drop us of. It was raining and we had to get ourselves through the pooring rain with our luggage into the building. We were greeted correctly and after check -in we had to carry our luggage to our room ourselves.The rooms are small with a bathroom that isn't worth mentioning. Feb 18 2009 	Good service spacious room	We stayed at the Clift for 3 nights recently after finding an amazing rate on Expedia ($163/night). The location is very good--just a few minutes walk from Union Square. The staff was friendly and helpful at every turn. When checking in my boyfriend asked if they could give us a complimentary upgrade if rooms were available and they gave us a junior suite. This was great given that the weather was terrible during our stay and we ended up spending more time than usual in our room. The living area of the suite was comfortable with plenty of seating, a television, and a desk. The sleeping area was small but perfectly adequate with a comfortable king-sized bed. There is also a TV in the sleeping area. The one space that needs real improvement is the bathroom. When the hotel was renovated they did a cheap "cover-up" job on the bathrooms. Ours was very small, with hardly enough room to open the door without hitting the toilet. The door was also coming off its hinge and didn't close properly. The tub was small and had been refinished (badly) and had chips in it. On the positive side, the shower (while the head is a bit low on the wall for a tall person) literally GUSHES water, which I love. Towels were plentiful and luxurious, and the provided bath products were very nice.The hotel charges $15/day for internet access from your own laptop, which is absurd. The business center charges $6.95 per 15 minutes of internet use and nearly $1 for each printed page. On the plus side, the business center DOES offer free boarding pass printing if you want to check in for your flights online. Also, there are no ice machines so if you want ice in your room you have to call room service, wait for them to bring up a bucket of ice, and tip the person who brings it to you. Why can't they just have an ice machine like almost every other hotel I have ever stayed in? Having said that, if you go to the bar and ask the bartender for a couple of glasses of ice to take to your room they are provided cheerfully. Overall, I would certainly stay here again if another good rate was offered.

Nov 9 2008 	Nice on the surface - but everything than professional or reliable	Being a Guest @ the Clift of San Francisco gives you great first impression - nice and stylish lobby with sofas made from /decorated with ivory teeth (Is that being allowed to be imported into the U.S.?).The room consits of cool designed interiors with added mirros - infinity style - so dont stay in there too long you my get dizzy ;-)They Serve Breakfast - dishes start @ around 25$ - the lame Continental Buffet is @ 30$ way to expensive - way tooooooo!Room Service is alway plus a lot of additional charges - not just the Tip.Valet Parking!!!Its a unbelivable 65,-- US$ per Night.Valet Parking is lame - I have waited a couple of times more than 30 Minutes for my ride.Restaurant and Bar are nice - lots of shiny people hanging out there - but as experienced - just get rid of their "overdose" in the lobby - honestly - we came back from a nice dinner and two guys were vomiting over the whole "nice" lobby - my wife will never go to the Clift again.Go there for a drink, Party or Dinner but never think of staying there to enjoy San Francisco or a business trip.Btw. Nov. 9th 2008

Sep 16 2008	Loved the Clift Hotel! Aug 28 2008 	Hicups	Upon arrival at 8 pm the confirmed type of rooms was not available. The lady at the receiption promissed to move us the next day around noon. Finally at 5 pm we received much bigger rooms than originally booked: Super huge suites!Same with some other services - It is like the left hand does not know what the right hand is doing: If you have your laundry picked up for cleaning service, they will return your laundry the same day, but not give you a new laundry bag. No big deal if they wouldn't charge you 35 bucks for the missing laundry upon departure. Or the mini bar: When you arrive, everything is great. You drink a bottle of wine the first night, they will remove the used wine glasses the next morning, but never give you new glasses. About the bar area: The bar is really nice and fun and fully packed with young local people on the weekends. All seats are "reserved", but there is no way you can reserve a seat in advance (even for hotel guests), unless you order a bottle of Vodka or better for 140 USD.They offer you seating in the lobby, which is very windy, if not stormy. Jul 5 2008 	Great hotel but not for everyone	The Clift is a wonderful hotel, but as the reviews reveal, you either love it or hate it. Jun 30 2008 	Worth going back to!	The Clift Hotel was amazing! Jun 23 2008 	We really liked it!!! Apr 30 2008	A great place to stay when you are in San Fran	I'd been to the infamous Red Wood Room bar in the Clift Hotel a number of times on past visits and always thought it would be nice to stay there - I finally got my chance last week! The Clift reminds me of the style of the W Hotel in that it is dark, opulent, contenporary and funky - the rooms are small but they are sexy and have large mirrors, drapes and are minimalist in design. The gym in the hotel was pretty limited but it did the job. No Spa or Jacuzzi either. But you know what? When you are staying in the CLift - you dont care, because it is a really cool place to stay and you are slap bang in the middle of town, and walking distance to the best shops in town in Union Square and some of the best places to go out (Slide and Vessel are two that spring to mind). Apr 28 2008 	Worst hotel experience ever!	I have stayed at a number of Shraeger properties around the world, this really was the worst.
