The room was DIRTY - there was a used condom under the bed and there was a used plaster in the toilet. The carpets were dirty and worn. One simply does not expect this sort of dirt in a supposedly good hotel.The furniture is from IKEA. For a hotel that is supposedly selling itself on design, this looked like a poster-child for how to furnish your room from IKEA in poor taste.The bathroom was tiny, stained and had cheap fixtures and a rusty rail. The shampoo etc in the bathroom were FUSED shut so you could not use them. Luckily we had some personal toilletries. The thing that irked me the most was that there was no water in room. Most good hotels have at least some complimentary water, if not water in the minibar. I have stayed very recently at the Clift and KNOW that you provide complimentary water on arrival - but this time round there was no water. There was no water in the minibar either. Had to call room service and then got CHARGED $15 for a bottle of WATER which costs $1.50 anywhere else. This was DAYLIGHT ROBBERY but as we had got to the hotel late, we were too tired. We told the front desk the next day and got a nonchalant and haughty reply from the front desk - and they claimed that they NEVER provide any complimentary water in the room and did not apologise for the fact that there was no water in the minibar - they did not even offer to take the water off the bill or at least reduce the price to what it would have been to buy it from the minibar. I think the barefaced lies and treatment after this was what irked me the most.The residents next door came back at 2 in the morning, shouting and singing. When we called downstairs, nothing was done to stop our drunk and disorderly neighbours from being a nuisance. Lastly, the front desk staff I spoke to about the water was just RUDE. I know the MOndrian group is about the "cool, snobby" attitude but that does not amount to customer service. The staff are more interested in whether they have enough hair gel and in chatting to each other than serving the customer. I have stayed at a number of Shraeger properties and have decided finally that for the price one pays, the design does not compensate for what are essentially low quality, poorly-serviced rooms with cheap bathroom fittings, toilletries and electronics (e.g. I don't know any other chain that still has box TVs - they are all flat screen except at the Clift which seems to have a bunch of TVs from the 80s).I never give feedback - but this stay was of SUCH low quality that I thought I would let others know. I plan to send this to journalist friends I have at Conde Nast and The Times in the UK. Apr 19 2008	The Clift Rocks	My colleague and I loved The Clift!!! I arrived in San Francisco on a 11 1/2 hour fligth - and was SO happy to be checked-in and given a good recommendation to eat at Dottie's down the way. When I check-in on Saturday the box my company had delivered was promptly brought up to my room. When I returned at night (fighting jet lag) did they think I was some kind of celebrity???....their was definitely an imaginary red carpet. The service quiet simply ROCKS. The welcome candy is a sweet gesture. Over the next few days I had the pleasure of staying at The Clift - the concierge, housekeeping, doormen...everyone definitely made their mark. In such a wonderful city, I could really care less about the size of the TV. The bathroom is industrial funky and I had no problems moving about drying my hair. The table/basin thing has a shelf below where there were lots of towels - and the robes were wonderful. Personally I'm confused about the comments about the availability of drawers. To me, aside from putting a few things on hangars - its normal to live out of a suitcase when travelling. Who has time to unpack everything just to be repacked again? LOLThe 9 hour differnece in time zones causes hungar at odd times occassionaly - the minibar has a diverse selection...drinks are expensive....its sorta like hint hint....don't stay in your room...we have the best bar in the city...come on down! The breakfast buffet was great and prompt....good for my colleague and I to be able to eat at a normal pace and not worry about waiting for service....quick quick!! The wifi was a bit slow - but the hotel was packed..maybe that's why...too many users??? My room was only on the 3rd floor but quiet. The lobby is always crazy at night but comfortable. I'm never happy with beds - they're always too hard for me! (so my opinion probably doesn't help much in that area) oh ...but see the last paragraph!From the other reviews I think there is a target market for this kind of hotel. Younger, chic, busy, image-concious...more interested in the redroom lounge than the size of tv.To everyone at The Clift on the morning of my departure - thank you for being so caring and coming upstairs after half an hour of trying to wake me. I'm glad you checked to make sure that I was okay ....it meant the world to me that you were so professional. See you soon! bisous bisous!

Jan 25 2008 	Jump off the Clift	Recently my family and I traveled to San Francisco to attend a family function in the Silicon Valley. Since we were only in the area for a long weekend, we decided to spend the first 2 nights in San Francisco. While previously we have stayed at the Fairmont and the Westin St. Francis, we decided to give the Clift a try due to a promotion that was being offered through American Express. Unfortunately our experience was not what we had anticipated. First, while the Clift is only 2 blocks from Union Square, it is not in a neighborhood where you want to walk at night. While San Francisco and for that matter, most major cities on the west coast have large homeless populations, such matter was most evident around the Clift. It seemed that at night you could not walk more than a couple of feet without bumping into a homeless person begging for money. In fact it appeared that some of these people were quite agressive. The hotel itself was obviously at some time an old apartment building or hotel which had been renovated. The lobby area is unique and clearly the hotel bar is a night spot for the single crowd. Unfortunately, the lighting is terrible. Such problem persisted throughout the hotel into the elevators and rooms. Our room was called a loft suite, but we use the word "suite" loosely. Really it was nothing more than an oversized room with a microsized bathroom. There was little lighting and the television was so small, you almost needed a microscope to see it. Moreover, you would have expected that a hotel with the purported reputation of the Clift would be luxurious. I would hardly classify it as a luxury hotel in the same class as the Fairmont. The staff was efficient, but certainly not friendly. We had to wait much too long to obtain our car and drop it off due to the fact that the staff was too busy handling the cars of patrons of the bar, obviously an important part of the financial operation. At over $50.00 per night to park our car, we expect priority service. Additionally, much of the staff wear earphones and dress like the secret service standing around and staring at everyone. I am not sure if these people are props in an effort to create a chic environment or just there to scare off anyone who walks through the door and may not be going to his or her room or the bar. All in all, I would not stay at the Clift again. There are too many more desirable hotels in San Francisco in much better neighborhoods and locations. As a side note, the hotel breakfast was great since it came with the room package, but without the package would be pricey. However, up the street off of Union Square is a restaurant called Sears. It is a San Francisco institution and I would highly recommend it for breakfast.

I guess it wasn't his $70 in cab rides and 2 hours wasted. I wrote a letter to the manager and they sent me a coupon for $50 off my next stay. OH BOY WHAT A DEAL. The party was good buy my friend was upset by the hotel service that he got after spending so much there. Also the hotel was a case of the emporers new clothes! The decor everyone raved about was straight out of clearance at IKEA!! I was not impressed by the snobbishness of it all. Good service includes graciousness. Also if they screw up they should take responsibility. This is the first complaint letter I have ever made. So much time has past since it happend but a friend just mentioned they would be booking some family here. I felt it important to list this so people weren't taken in by this supposed 5 star hotel.

Dec 15 2007	Can't believe this is a 5-star hotel	If I didn't pay $129 per night through expedia, I would have been pretty upset. Stayed 4 nights. Internet service in the room is $10.00 per day RIPOFF. Dec 9 2007 	Service Was Good!	I think it's important to know what you want when you book a hotel in San Francisco. Me, I want grandiose!!! I thought with "The Clift" I was giving up grandiose for contemporary greatness. It was ok.I want a hotel that "WOWs" me when I walk in.. The Clift was dark, and just ok to me. I should have payed better attention to those other reviews.SERVICE: Upon arrival the doorman were great. I never opened a door for myself as other poster have stated. We even used the semi-limonsine service that parks out front to get around. Expensive, but we were celebrating our anniversary and didn't care about the cost, not for that, at least. The front desk was also helpful and even gave us a 2:30 late check outROOM: It was big, since we booked a junior suite, but the bed was very hard. There were two TV's in the room but they are pretty small. I didn't care so much about that, since I was not there to watch TV.REDWOOD ROOM: OK, here is where I don't get it. So to be hip you hang out at the Redwood Room. We arrived back to the hotel after seeing a play, and we got help from one of the ladies at the door in getting a drink. That was nice. What I didn't like was they played very loud "hip" music. I was on my anniversay, and wanted to dance, but no one was dancing, slow or fast. The dance floor was somewhere in the back with people standing on it and talking, I think. Never could make it back that far in the room. My daughter later told me that nowadays, they don't play slow music to dance, until right before closing, if even then. The people were all crowded around yelling at one another, since you can't hear cause the music is so loud. To get a table at The Clift you have to buy a "bottle" of some kind of booze, starting at $200.00+. It was the end of our evening, around midnight, and weren't going to pound down a bottle or even close, so we got no seat. My husband and I stood there and watched people. It's a younger crowd mainly, with a few old foogies trying to pick up on young women. Not my scene. No view, no seat, and I did not see one celebrity, just some young people with cute attire. I'm in SF and I want a view and some ambience, something, but at the Redwood room, I could have easily been been in someone's garage for what it was.OVERALL: I would give this hotel three stars. I should have booked the Fairmont or any other Hotel in Nob Hill, or maybe the St. Regis or the Hilton. Not sure how it can be identified as a Four star hotel, since that's just one star from being a "fairmont, or St. Regis. This is a three star at best.

Nov 30 2007	Great decor but beware of the tiny bathrooms!	Expensive, ultra trendy, but disappointing for the money.The Clift is a boutique style hotel right in the heart of San Francisco's downtown art gallery district and within easy walking distance of Union Square, awesome art galleries and photo galleries and the nightclubs and bars of the city.The major downfall is that the hotel bathrooms at The Clift hardly have enough room to swing a cat and for the price paid (around $300 per room per night) it isn't all that great. Nov 23 2007 	Hip Hype	This was a special birthday trip for my husband and I wanted it to be special, so spent more $$ than I normally would on the hotel. Nov 12 2007 	Will never return to the Clift	Overall I really disliked this hotel. I met an old college room mate Nov 5-8/07 and she booked the room. Nov 12 2007 	Superb but expensive experience	The Clift is a five-star experience in every respect. As a frequent patron before the remodel, it is a shock to see the French decor give way to the new minimalist look. The rooms are pretty white with the two walls covered with mirrors to make the smallish room seem much larger. Fine quality bedding makes for a luxurious nights sleep. In keeping with an eco-friendly environment, it is a little dim in the entry way and no light in the closet.The staff was friendly and helpful, at the front desk, concierge and the front door staff. The rain interrupted the smooth flow of traffic, and we had 20 minute waits both to drop off our car and to retreive it. Everyone was working hard and helpful, but the infrequent rains in San Frnacisco seemed to overwhelm them.The main dining room was fabulous. The unusual blend of Asian and Cuban cuisine was delicious and presented boldly with lots and lots of food. Our waiter was friendly, knowledgeable and helpful -- especially about not ordering too much as the portions were huge. The scallops were perfect; our calamari salad was delicious, and we split a main course of steak that was so tender it could be cut with a fork. Everyone was quite pleasant and helpful.Overall, it was an outstanding experience. Close to Union Square and shopping. Nov 10 2007	Excellent service great location nice rooms	I don't understand the other reviews about service being poor - my experience (8-10 Nov 07) was quite the opposite with very friendly and attentive staff wherever I went in the hotel.I got upgraded to a one-bed suite, including 8 seater dining table. Nov 8 2007 	Debacle of a hotel	Classic case of a hotel pretending to be nice when it really isn't. A few things:1. Terrible service at the Redwood Room. Terrible.2. Nov 6 2007	Hmmm... Firealarm at 3 am and walls like paper.. Stay again? No	We stayed here for 2 night in November. Nov 2 2007	rude wannabees!!!	Don't waste your time going to the Cliff Hotel! We went there during our anniversary and walked out in disbelief! Oct 20 2007 	Simply loved the Clift!	If you ever spend some time in San Francisco, you have to stay at the Clift. If you're lucky like us, you get a room on one of the upper floors where the rooms are bigger. Make sure not to stay next to the elevator, it's a bit noisy. The service was also perfect. Oct 10 2007 	Sleek and stylish hotel	A friend booked us into the Clift for a night as a surprise. What a treat!This is a very swish and stylish hotel, designed by Phillip Starck. The room itself was a small suite; very calm, modern and comfortable in design. It had some nice luxuries like a CD player, huge TV and thick lustrous curtains.Designwise, downstairs is more exciting. The wood panelled Redwood Bar on the ground floor is amazing, made (I believe) from a single tree it is dark and atmospheric. In fact, darkness seemed to be a design theme running through other areas such as the corridors. The bar, dispensing excellent if pricey cocktails, is all lit up and the art on the walls is very cool and contemporary - video screens that on our visit were showing photographic portraits that if you watched closely you would see move now and then.It's a pricey place though, and I'm not sure that the extra money really buys you anything more than some nice design. Oct 9 2007 	An absolute must!! Oct 8 2007 	Untraditional Hotel	We just returned from a trip to SF and stayed at the Clift. Reason being, it was difficult to get any hotels at all in the union square area, and not knowing how close all the neighborhoods are to one another, we didn't want to be stuck in an area we couldn't walk around in. The premise to stay in this area is so that you can easily walk the neighborhoods and get around easily . See more about this at the end of this review...for now, pros and consPros: close to theatres, chinatown, within walking distance or trolley or bus to wharf, north beach, telegraph hill, etc.People were VERY nice - our experience was not that they were snooty. Concierge and front desk arranged for rental car once we were leaving the area to drive down the coast, restaurant recommendations, etc.Bartender not as friendly but servers very friendly and we received fast service in the bar which is where we ate. Bar very trendy, great people watching - this is a great place where many trendies go. 20-30 somethings love this place.Very unique experience - most hotels are all alike in many ways; this hotel truly stands out as unique.Business center costs 6.95 to use internet for 15 minutes; but it's a cool area with lots of plasma tvs.Good workout area.Cons: the room details listed by other reviewers I'm in agreement on; no coffee makers or water in the room is just silly - and none even in the lobby. Nowhere to put stuff! shelves in bathroom are workable, but really not much room to move.Nowhere to put stuff - for extended stays, crowded and no drawers.For the more mature traveler, or business traveler, it may be too different - and trendiness versus value overall won't win.For the money, the value just isn't here. Additional:This is in the theatre district, but the other districts are within a block of this - so very easy to get around. But you really want to be walking versus taking cabs in this central area of theatre, financial, shopping, chinatown...because there is a lot of traffic here like many downtown areas.Very casual everyplace - you can dress up or down, mostly casual.

Sep 23 2007 	Not all that great and too expensive	The hotel looks like a club when you come in. The Reception and lobby area is dark and decorated with a lot of wood and concrete (in a good way). The hallway's are purple the elevators all have a different colour and there's a constant funky music in the reception, lobby, and even in the elevators.The rooms are small and decorated with big mirrors in front and behind the bed. The colours used are interesting as well partialy purple walls and furniture and orange cubic bed stands. Personally i didn't like it. The bathroom is really small. The closet is a doorhole with a shelf and somekind of small trendy drawer. not all that functional.The Bar is decorated completly in wood and is really nice. Especially the living portraits. If you want to sit down it's going to cost you a pricy bottle of liquer and you need to reserve.The restaurant looks nice and they offer pricy fushion food which you are supposed to share amongst the able. The food is good but the service not. The waiting time is long as well.Another interesting feature is the week-end transformation. The bar one of the town's hotspots and people stand in line to get in. Sep 19 2007 	Avoid the Clift Hotel	The Clift Hotel is the worst place I have stayed in San Francisco. - Arrive after 8pm and stand in line to get questioned by the doorman/bouncer. The trendy restaurant and bar flow over to the Hotel Lobby so I understand why; but not cool after finishing a day of meetings. Do not stay here unless you are here to party and do not feel can make it across the street to any of the nearby hotels.- Washroom was super small. Sep 15 2007 	Incongruent design	The Clift was marketed as a 4-star boutique hotel in downtown SF. It was indeed downtown and had all the hallmarks of a funky boutique hotel, but 4-star? Absolutely not.The lobby was darkly decorated with rich wood, a huge (and I mean HUGE) sitting chair - I think you needed a small ladder to get on the seat - lots of couches and a friendly staff, but there was no doorman there when we arrived at 5:30 PM on a Friday night.As we checked in, no offer of a bellman to get our bags to our room and when we entered the elevator, it was like the twilight zone. The first elevator we rode on was mirrored on the inside with red mirrors. Dizzying, in my opinion, especially when we stepped off the elevator on our floor to a vague lavender colour. Other elevators were blue mirrors and green mirrors. Oy.Our room was a lovely corner room, very small, but we were mindful of the fact that this was an OLD hotel property (I think it was originally a Four Seasons hotel) and the rooms from that grand era are much smaller than today. The furniture was blond wood and modern and someone had seen fit to paint a flourescent coral color on the underneath of the furniture to give it a "glow". All well and good, except the paint was peeling off.The bathroom was fully mirrored (but in regular plain mirrors rather than the colored mirrors of the elevator, thank God!) and it gave a nice bright feel. The provided toiletries were fabulous - basil lemon (I think!) bar soap in a cool plastic case, shower gel, and so on.We went to dinner and a show in the Mission District and when we returned to the hotel after midnight, the doorman had finally appeared and wasn't going to let us in without our key, even though there was a super-packed bar scene happening right beyond the lobby. I guess our Mission District casual outfits wouldn't have passed muster in the bar and we were only let in because we both produced a room key.Check out was quick and painless, no weird charges we had to dispute, and again, friendly staff at the counter.Overall, definitely a three-star but in no one way does it come close to the four-star it was marketed as.

Sep 11 2007 	All fur and no knickers	For the final leg of our honeymoon we decided to stay at The Clift in San Francisco. We expected a chi-chi designer hotel and certainly from the lobby/reception areas it is impressive (also very very dark). On arrival the receptionist was precise and quick, less hospitable than the other hotels we'd stayed at for sure.We got to our room and saw what we expected. Small city centre hotel with a tiny bathroom. However what did make us slightly sad was the tiredness of the room. It certainly has not been touched since its conversation by Starck and Shrager. Minimalist to the letter, there were no frills associated with any other 5* hotel. Everything had to be paid for. The TV was a let down (sad I know to have to comment on this). It was an old school Philips 20inch TV - probably the same age as the hotel. Most good quality hotels - particularly those who consider themselves 5* and boutique would have had a plasma and not a 'box' in a console (also containing the mini-bar).The bathroom was obviously the original from the Clift but I can accept that although the chic bowl and stand table didn't fit with the vintage bath, tiles and toilet fixtures. Seems to me to be a lot of laziness in terms of trying to finish the job off.Linens were soft and comfortable but the towels were appalling. Pulled threads and worn out in places. Not what you would expect.Staff were reasonably polite and helpful (although it wasn't clear who was operating the concierge but then I didn't ask at first).Asia de Cuba was a success, although we were informed that portions were large and were recommended to choose just one appetiser and one entree. Not a problem if you both eat meat/fish but if you don't then the meat eater could get left out. Best bet is to order 2/3 appetisers instead. The carrot cake was amazing also but enough for 3 people!! Our meal including two glasses of wine each plus water and coffee is $168.00 which isn't that bad compared with UK prices. But choose wisely..The Redwood Room was avoided on Friday and Saturday due to the number of people in there (mainly external I believe). I think this is where the hotel lets its guests down, it doesn't provide a private residents bar which it should considering its status and price.Overall it was okay but not worth visiting again. I've stayed in hotels all over Europe and also the Bellagio and Loews. The Clift needs to revisit its guest experience in my opinion.

Since I have stayed at the Morgan (NYC) several times I assumed we would have a pleasant experience and I LOVE Asia de Cuba in NYC. I was wrong!  When we arrived at the Clift, the doorman did not even open the door or even aknowledge our pressence. Check-in was smooth but the girl was certainly rushing us and annoyed with any questions. Our original plan was to spend our first night with dinner at Asia De Cuba and start off with some early evening cocktails at the Redwood Room. BIG MISTAKE. Upon check-in we asked if we needed reservations for the Redwood Room. The girl gave us some "preferred customer" cards of some sort which she explained would get us right in with no problem. We approached the hostess at about 730 pm. There were a couple of guys in front of us whom the hostess was assisting. As we patiently waited, a large group came up behind us. The matron of the group approached the hostess - cutting in front of everyone else AND interrupting the conversation between the hostess and the 2 guys. Rather than telling this RUDE woman to go stand in line actually assisted her! The guys in front of us looked apalled and we were infuriated. Once it was finally our turn (like that mattered to the hostess) she very rudely told us we couldnt come in without a reservation. She said she had people arriving at 9 pm. We explained we just wanted ONE pre-dinner cocktail. At this point she got even more rude. At this point we decided this was NOT a place we wanted to spend out money anyways. They obviously dont care about their actual guests! The scene was horrible anyways. I dont think there was a patron under the age of 65 in the entire bar.... so much for a "hip" bar scene. We tried to complain to a manager but he was too busy having a personal conversation with one of the doormen. We decided our money is better spent elsewhere and opted against dinner in the hotel. We had a lovely meal in the Marina district then went on to drinks at Matrix where our patronage was appreciated and our drinks were not accompanied with a side of rudeness. I might also point out the martinis are $8 at Matrix as opposed to the overpriced drinks Redwood Room with serve you along with their snooty attitude. We are from LA so we are no strangers to attitude but this was just plain RUDE.  Aside from the horrible experience our first night, the hotel lobby is quite nice. The rooms are VERY small and somewhat dirty. The bathroom is appalling - dirty towels, the fan doesnt work, no standing room. On our final day, the anger from night one had worn off slightly (probably because we spent as little time in the hotel as possible). We were packing our stuff and relaxing from a morning of shopping. The day before, housekeeping entered our room even though we had the "do not disturb" sign on the door. Since nothing was taken we ignored it. Now here we are, a mere hour from escaping the Clift, when there is a knock at the door...housekeeping. I explain we are leaving at 1 (check out time) and to please respect the "do not disturb" sign. 15 minutes later, another knock at the door. It is the housekeeper AGAIN. I tell her "we are still here" and remind her of our departure time. Sure enough, another knock at the door and who could it be? The SAME housekeeper. At this point we are so frustrated my boyfriend tells her to wait outside and we gather all our stuff (half packed and all). They clearly wanted us gone so we sprinted to the elevator checked out and left the Clift behind.  Trust me, the Clift offers NOTHING to validate such horrible attitudes and behavior. I had high hopes for this place and if they had impressed me, I would have considered staying there on my monthly business trips up to SF. Forget it. I will definately tell everyone I know NOT to stay here and I will probably never stay at the Morgan again either just because of the Clift affiliation. Trust me, you are better off at the Sir Francis Drake or the Westin. At least they know you exist there and are gracious for your patronage. My advice to the Clift, perhaps you should remember that you are serving your guests not vice versa. Thank you for putting a stain on an otherwise lovely trip.

Sep 2 2007	Really nice great location!	Its a trendy hotel, a real beauty on the inside. Great bar scene, and the food was great too. The rooms are nice, great views, and a comfy bed. The TV was horrible, just 12 inches...they said they are working on that aspect. Morgans Hotels are fun and hip. You can't go wrong. Breakfast staff and waiters in Asia De Cuba were amazing!

Sep 1 2007 	Great Hotel and Service	My husband and I just got back from San Francisco where we stayed at the Clift hotel. We had an excellent time and can't say enough good things about the hotel and the service we received. The first night at the hotel we couldn't sleep because there was a service elevator next to our room which was loud and kept us up all night. We called front desk in the morning and they switched us to another beautiful room later that day. The hotel is well situated near Union Sq. and close to the public transit. The hotel is very clean and friendly staff. We especially recommend talking to Steve the concierge. He was so helpful in recommending great restaurants and things to do around San Francisco. He also recommended that instead of taking an organized tour of the Napa Valley like my husband and I wanted to do, he arranged a car rental for us and gave us great driving directions to go there on our own. That was really the high light of our trip. He made our own little itinerary so we were able to see the vineyards we wanted to see and even made lunch reservations at a wonderul restaurant for us. Overall great service!

Aug 26 2007	Excellent Location Beautiful but Not Worth The Money	Clift is a very beautiful hotel -- the lobby is stunning, the furniture is gorgeous, the elevators are sexy, I loved the periwinkle and silver decorations and thought the hotel room was very pretty. Aug 24 2007 	Nightclub posing as a 4 star hotel	The hotel itself was gorgeous. The staff was superb. Also, on the morning I left, the Internet access was shut off hours before checkout time.Given the internet shutoff, the housekeeping coming by as I was in the shower, and the charge sheet unceremoniously shoved under the door in the early morning, I felt as though I was being shoved out the door. Jul 26 2007 	Best hotel in SF!	I spend a lot of time in the Bay area primarily for business and have tried most of the usual suspects but keep coming back to the Clift time and time again. The room amenities are the best I've found in the city; Ian Schraeger-designed so you know they'll be visually interesting and appealing to most, plenty of space, ambiance lighting, candles, outrageously comfortable beds, lots of bathroom counter/shelf space, Frette robes... nothing is left to spare! Jul 1 2007	Dark 	The Clift lobby was very dark and cool. Staff was always pleasant, but not overly friendly. Their counterparts at The Hudson in NYC should take a leaf from their training book. We were upgraded in advance (without asking) to suite 1533, a beautiful, bright and crisp corner room. The Clift is boutique and cool in style, the bar can be a bit dark and overpowering but worth a cocktail to people watch. Talking of that - have a look at the 'paintings' on the walls - very cool....The concierge dealt with our every need - travel advice, restaurant reservations, airport car, and even liasing with vegas with regards items left in our room there. We did not eat in the hotel as there is so much cool food in SF. A 'tourist' photo sitting in the big chair in the lobby is a must...but most imprtantly - experiencing The Clift is also a must. Excellent location - 1.5 blocks from Union Sq, close to tram/bus links. Professional and friendly service. Funky design but still very comfortable. Californian, laid back cooool.........We would go back in a heartbeat

Apr 25 2007 	Very nice.	We just returned from a five day stay at the Clift. We are in are late 50's and very much enjoyed the hotel. Staff is very friendly and accomodating. Arrived late due to flight problems and check in was accomodating. We had Theater tickets so that was essential. Surprised to find Theater was virtually next door which gave us some crucial minutes. ctually spent very little time in the room which is typical for us so room size was not an issue. Room was very nice and comfortable. We do not expect or need an enormous room. We thought decor was interesting and different. Those complaining about city issues, it is to be expected, but not threatening in the least. Clift staff is always outside welcoming you. The Redwod Room is rather amazing. We got a very good deal on room which of course made a lot of difference.

Apr 7 2007 	Just returned from the Clift	My wife and I just returned from the wonderful city of San Francisco. If you have never gone, well worth the trip. Not a ton to do, but the ambiance and relaxed state of the city is soothing itself. Definitely check out the usual tourist traps (Alcatraz, Pier 39, Chinatown) and if you like art head over to the SFMOMA. There was gallery dedicated to Picasso's prevalent role in developing modern/post modern artists.So about this hotel..... First of all if you are going ask yourself some specific questions...1) am I looking for a hotel to be chic and attempting the cutting edge of design (trying to make an artistic statement)?if you could care less or are not impressed with this previous statement, you may not like the Clift Hotel. This hotel is just like its sister in South Beach, The Delano. It is a great scene to be scene, have an amazing night (Redwood Room) and eat a fantastic, yet expensive meal (Asia De Cuba). Overall, I really felt like this was a couples hotel, friends looking to get out and party around SF hotel, business hotel, and romantic hotel, not really a family with kids hotel.2) Am I looking for a hotel with a large room and bathroom?Just like NYC and a couple of other large metropolitan areas, there just aren't many hotels with large rooms/bathrooms. The Clift's bathroom is small like most hotels (W Hotel, Hotel Diva, Hiltons, Marriots) in the city.My overall impressions:ServiceBell Hops all the way up to management and front desk workers were extremely polite, friendly, and welcoming. They took our bags up to our room immediately, brought in room service promptly with a smile, and even were very friendly at the Redwood Bar getting us a table quickly without extra charges. When we checked out, our bags did not make it out to the car right away and our car was a few minutes late. The doorman was immediately on his phone and little radio twice to correct the situation promptly. I have read negative reviews about the service about six months ago on this site. These reviews are now false b/c either management was changed or they changed their style of customer service. Either way, smart move Clift, your service will keep bringing people back.RoomSmall, but so are the majority of rooms in SF. Great king sized bed with comfortable sheets/comforter. Pillows are down so if you are allergic (wife is) just call down to housekeeping and they will accomodate your needs. Bathroom is small but not completely terrible. There are also mirrors in the room which can make it a tad bit easier when getting ready to go out for the night. Only suggestion for this hotel is purchase some better quality towels. The white, holiday inn style doesn't fit.Lobby/Bars/RestaurantsThe lobby can definitely throw you off if you don't expect it. There is a huge fireplace, oversized chair (like the seat is six feet off the ground), amongst other eccentric nic-nacs. Great library/sitting area with classic board games to pass the time.Redwood Room is a great bar. It has a beautiful design, plenty of seating (if you are lucky to get some), and a huge bar. Don't pass this place up. Great mix of a crowd age wise as well. Just fun, not pretentious like some of the bars/clubs in South Beach, Vegas, LA, etc.Asia De Cuba seemed like a nice restaurant. Didn't get there for dinner or lunch, but had a good breakfast. Seemed trendy, but never heard a complaint from anyone who ate there. We got a great deal on the price (below $200), but even if it was $250/$300 a night, we would definitely come back (unless the Four Seasons or Ritz was the same price). Great time and wonderful overall experience. Thanks Clift!

Apr 1 2007	Disfunctional Design	From halfway across the world we were seduced to select the Clift Hotel in San Francisco in which to spend our first night in the city,by its glamorous web site, promising a first rate designer environment and luxury. Tired after trans-Atlantic and trans-continental flights we fought our way through heavy glass doors, unaided by doormen, bellhops, or staff of any other description and entered a gloomy, cavernous interior. The trademark oversized chair, tusk-backed sofa, Perspex chairs and assorted leather furniture presented no coherent design aesthetic. Ironically, the Clift Hotel was one of the first hotels that popped up on a Google search for family friendly hotels in San Francisco.Our ten year old daughter, herself well traveled, described the hotel instantly as "creepy". After checking in we were still offeredno assistance whatsoever with our luggage and had to manage our own way to our room in dark and gloomy lifts more suited to seedy night clubs than luxury hotels. As for the room, it appeared to have been decorated with bargain basement sales items in the nature of paints, carpets, curtains and wall hangings that would not otherwise have sold. Grey carpet met chintzy beige curtains, lilac, purple and white paints, beech furniture and fake and uncomfortable French period-style chairs. Copious mirrored walls were apparently meant to balance the unbalancable lot.The bathroom design was undoubtedly copied from 1970s state hospital bathroom designs. The bathroom space itself was large enough to have allowed an architect or interior designer with any talent to have come up with a comfortable and functional use of space. Instead, there is a low and small bath with no space for headrest, over embellished with large stainless steal protrusions and a poorly designed bath/shower apparatus. There should be no place for shower curtains in luxury hotels! The basin is tiny with no space for toiletries. If all this does not make for an uncomfortable bathing experience already, the fog horn style noise of what was either the plumbing or the exhaust fan was migraine inducing. The bathrobes, which are typically meant to be inviting to guests, were bound and knotted up, tight as mummies, so that one finally gave up the effort to put one on. Walls in the hotel are clearly porous and made of paper. We were woken at 3:00 AM by guests in a neighbouring room who carried on for more than an hour a normal but inane conversation, of which we could do no other but lie and listen to every single word.Staff in general were either absent or wholly disinterested in the hotels clients. We could not leave soon enough. If this hotel represents San Franciscos design aspirations, aesthetic sense and hospitality, the city should be worried. We will gladly pay for beauty, comfort, efficiency and friendly service. We found none of these qualities at the Clift Hotel.

Mar 9 2007 	Great service..how a 5-stars should be	We had recently a 4-nights stay in San Francisco on the way to our Honeymoon. Before arriving I called the hotel to warn that we were up for a late-check in, the girl at the phone was exquisitely kind and confirmed me that they would be waiting for us. Check-in went smooth and quick, we got a complimentary upgrade to a junior-suite. The room was nice and clean, the design great (hey, I reckon I'm design-addicted), the bed super-comfortable and they have great sheets. Great lightings and atmosphere. Enough choice for breakfast and for (midnight)snacks, (in both cases you got different menu's to choose from), everything was delivered quite timely. The only minus: the bathroom is really very small! For the rest we totally enjoyed our stay, perfect service, from the beginning to the end: professional, kind and always ready to make us feel welcome and to satisfy our requests. This is how a four stars should be! We loved the place, the atmosphere, the Redwood-Room, the fire-place and the attitude...and of course, the location! Great & hip place to stay when in SFO!

Mar 5 2007 	100% Great Experience	This review is for a one night stay (March 3 - 4) in room #1128.Upon arriving at the hotel (friend and I walked from Powell Street BART Station), I immediately noticed that they had finally put a sign on the exterior (metal letters, set discreetly on the front of the building by the entrance). When we started walking past the tree pots set on the outside Geary Street wall of the building, my friend said, "I already think I am going to like this place" due to the understated but stylish exterior vibe.Upon entering the fantastically designed lobby, we encountered no line at check-in. My friend went off to ogle the spectatcular design elements while I dealt with check-in. The woman handling that was friendly and welcoming...in fact, none of the snottiness pointed out in some other reviews was encountered by us with any of the staff during this visit. But we are smiley, friendly people so maybe that's what we got back? Who knows -- I just felt very welcome the entire visit.We then took the opportunity to enjoy a drink in the Redwood Room before the party scene started -- it's a stunning space, and the redesign of several years ago was sympathetic and successful. Going when it is quiet may not be a party highlight, but it is certainly an opportunity to enjoy the magnificence of this space -- and a good cocktail!When we got to the room, we discovered that the management had delivered a bottle of sparkling wine (Gloria Ferrer blanc de noir) and a lovely flower arrangement, with their compliments. Most kind of them!Our purpose for coming to the Clift this time was to host a 40th birthday party for a friend, including 10 guests, so we had booked a 925 square foot one-bedroom suite with living and dining area. It was spectatcular -- very large, private, quiet and beautifully designed with loads of windows and large wall mirrors to keep things bright and several pieces of custom Phillipe Starck furniture that are unique to that room. There is an 8-place oval dining table covered with a custom cut piece of orange mirror glass. Wild! But very sophisticated, too. It's "freaky-chicy" as one of our guests said.The room service team arranged everything perfectly -- four hot appetizers had been ordered a week before-hand, as well as red wine glasses, Champagne flutes and iced Champagne buckets (we bought our own wine at the very well-appointed wine shop two blocks away -- Moet & Chandon White Star and Stags Leap Wine Cellars "Artemis"). By the way -- we got NO bad vibes at all about bringing our own wine and the people in room service, in the days before our arrival, were a pleasure to work with. We asked to have everything set up by 6:30pm and it was done by 6:40pm. Pretty good!The room is great for entertaining, and after two hours or so, we all left for the Vivienne Westwood party at the DeYoung Museum. Upon returning close to midnight, some of us enjoyed cocktails and appetizers in the Living Room area, which was dark and private -- the Redwood Room is a great place to party, but we were too pooped to deal with that scene.We slept soundly in the excellent bed and in the morning were shouting for joy over the strongest water pressure from a hotel shower either of us had experienced in quite some time! The bathroom has ample space for personal effects and the dressing room outside the bathroom has a table-with-mirror and huge closets for even more storage.We requested a late check-out at 2pm which was immediately approved. Then we went downstairs to enjoy our breakfast. The Asia de Cuba french toast was amazing -- it had a veritable mountain of whipped cream -- and bravo to the restaurant for also offering "design it yourself" egg-white omelettes for those of us fat-averse types! Breakfast was not cheap but we had a couple Mimosas, so it was our own fault! LOL And if you want cheap, there are a couple greasy spoons a block or two up Geary that serve good diner food (I think one is called the Olympic Flame and I've had good eggs-toast-and-bacon brekkies there).Check-out was a breeze and there were no "hidden charges" on the bill. Once again, the staff just could not have been more friendly -- even the cleaning staff one passed in the halls smiled and said "Hello."I had some fears about the complexity of the expectations I had of the hotel -- the food, getting it set up, making sure it was a memorable and flavorful 40th birthday for my friend -- and I just could not be more pleased. They got EVERYTHING right.I will most certainly be returning to The Clift....in fact, I have the same room booked for July 6! Good job to everyone at the hotel and thank you for making my friend's 40th birthday truly special.

Feb 28 2007 	over priced - no value here	Stayed here for the weekend. We were here for a family event. We asked if we could get connecting rooms. Not possible. Everytime we came and left the hotel we were attacked by panhandlers. We ate in the resturant Sunday morning 7 adults and 2 children for breakfast was $249. Rooms were small but clean. We brought our own beer into the mini bar, so they took the bottle opener out of there so we could not open our beer.We will not return.

Feb 18 2007 	Average in everything except the price	The hotel has a very good location 1.5 blocks from Union Square. The Service was adequate and the rooms were clean but small. Also I think the hotel is overpriced for the service they are providing.

Feb 17 2007 	Traveler be aware.....	Purchased a trip through Orbitz - picked this hotel because of the excellent ratings. Lovely lobby, but... be aware that this hotel does enforce its policy of surcharging at the time of check in. Feb 14 2007	Very Good Customer Service	I recently wrote about my dissatisfaction with the Clift Hotel's New Year's Eve 2007 VIP Party. After speaking with Lauren we were informed that this event was managed by a 3rd party.In addition, Lauren gave us the contact information for Uncorked Events. They assured us that this is not their normal business practice and we are working toward a partial refund.Thanks Clift Hotel and Uncorked for protecting your brand.Very Impressive Customer Service and it leaves us feeling like their is something to be said about dealing with reputable businesses such as yours! Although I wasn't able to delete my prior posting, I want to make sure i note that your hotel understands and manages situations very well.Thanks again.

Feb 14 2007 	ignore the bad press	just had to post a review after reading the negative comments posted previously. i spent 2 weeks at the clift last year, travelling from australia specifically to stay at the hotel. i could not fault the 14 nights there. yes the hotel is located at the corner of the tenderloin districts start - but so what ? exit the hotel - turn right and you are 5 mins from union square ! the hotel was spotless, the staff great, the rooms fine - it was a great experience. ignore the negatives - give the place a try, and if you have amex platinum enjoy the room upgrades. and by the way - i don't work for morgans hotel group :)

Feb 9 2007	Overpriced with bad service	Avoid this place at all cost. It is located in San Francisco's Tenderloin District, one of the worst crime ridden areas of the city. Don't believe the type about its fashion designed interior or its proximity to Union Square, it is not safe to walk around at night and the rooms are tiny and dirty. This place is nothing more than a glammed up residential hotel. Also, don't believe the positive reviews on this site which were undoubtedly posted by the management. You can find much nicer hotels at much more reasonable rate than this place.

Feb 6 2007 	Terrible Wedding Night Stay - Very Disappointed	I know I'm writing this review late, considering I stayed at this hotel in 2004, but I recently joined TripAdvisor, so I felt the need to write a review on it since I have stayed at this establishment in the past.My husband and I had just gotten married in October of 2004 and after LOTS of research, we decided to spend our wedding night at the Clift Hotel after getting married that afternoon in Sausalito. Upon arriving at the hotel, we were greeted by a very SNOBBY staff who didn't seem to care that we had just gotten married and never even bothered to utter one word of congratulations. Fine. Whatever. Then they told us to leave our bags with the bellhop and he would bring it up to our room. Needless to say, we waited over 45 minutes for the bellhop to arrive and finally, after calling the front desk twice (couldn't get through the first time), he finally arrived. He gave us a very nasty look of contempt when he walked out the door without a dime in his hands, since we decided that giving a tip would actually send the message that his service was remotely adequate.When we arrived to the room, we were extremely disappointed. The feature sheet describes the rooms as "Large windows with panoramic city views overlooking the Golden Gate Bridge, as well as other San Francisco landmarks." Let me tell you, the only view I got was of the brick wall looking onto the neighboring apartment building through a tiny window. Another huge disappointment, especially considering this was our wedding night.Like the other reviewers said, the bathroom was TINY and had absolutely no room for toiletries. I can't believe the feature sheet had the nerve to say "Bathrooms - comfortable, OVERSIZED, and luxurious"!!! What the heck??? The room itself was very small, considering the large pricetag you have to pay. Again, someone needs to revise that feature sheet that says "The 363 rooms at Clift are GENEROUSLY scaled and beautifully appointed." Or do they mean the rooms are generously scaled to fit a mouse?The only highlight of our stay was the bed. I had the best night of sleep I've had in a very long time. It is the only reason I would give this review 2 stars, but after all the negatives, not even the bed can make up for everything else to give it the extra star.I am a native of the Bay Area and know that there are many other establishments to stay in San Francisco where the service and amenties are far superior than the Clift Hotel.Considering my stay at the Clift was on my wedding night, I will always have a bad taste in my mouth when I consider how awful and disappointing my stay was on what was supposed to be one of the most special evenings of my life.

Jan 23 2007	Fine hotel great location excellent service -- and a parking tip	Spent 5 nights at the Clift over Christmas. I'd read some of the negative reviews and had started to wonder, but I knew the location and the bar and thought I'd give it a chance any way. Very glad I did.ROOMSHad the junior suite and was very pleased. Two rooms about the same size (225 sq. feet each, 450 total), living area with one large window with a great view to Nob Hill, king size bed with dresser and bench in the other. Desk, sofa and some comfy chairs, a small entertainment center in the living room. (Yes the TV's are small but I didn't go to San Francisco to get caught up on CSI.) Kind bed in the bedroom was extrememly comfortable, the pillows and sheets as well and the duvet nice enough to want to steal/buy. The colors throughout were soft pastels, and both room had lots of mirrors that help spread the light and open the space. The bathrooms were fine, perhaps on the small side but for those who don't understand why you can't find Vegas size rooms in SF hotels, take a look around. The old architecture,especially in the theater district and down town, doesn't allow for it. The charm of hotels like these is that they still have the original feel despite the modern renovations. That said, it's also worth noting the water pressure was still amazing, which often isn't the case in the larger, older structures that might still have old plumbing -- no problem here.SERVICEI often travel over the holidays and have come to accept that most hotels and restaurants are under staffed during the holiday season and often things take a little longer to get done. Not the case here. House keeping was exemplary -- every minor request cared for almost instantly and with a smile. The front desk was friendly, always helpful without a trace of the mysterious "attitude" some people on here seem to be complaining of. Yes, they're younger and had nicer hair cuts than me, but they were still very professional at all times. (Only one minor complaint -- the door man did in fact seem to be invisible during our stay, which was only an issue when checking in.)THE BAR/RESTAURANTThe bar may be a bit of a scene, but with good reason: it's a great place to sit and have a drink, and the bartenders pour liberally. The redwood walls and art deco bar are understandable a tourist attraction in their own right. Even Christmas eve the bar was full and the staff a little overwhelmed, but a very friendly bar manager rolled up his sleeves and did his best to help out, giving away any of his mistakes and even many of the drinks he poured correctly. (I can't count the number of drinks that never appeared on my tab during my stay there.) Yes weekend table service is pricey -- a few hundred for a bottle wine (more for hard liquor) for the luxury of a table can be a bit much. It's also standard at any bar of that style and caliber, and the answer for those who don't want to spend that much is simple: go before 10 pm, or on a week night, or just muscle up to the bar. Or bring a bunch of friends and split the bill. Either way it's worth checking out.The restaurant, Asia de Cuba, is also beautiful and connects to the bar. The staff is friendly, the portions generous and contrary to what some say not that pricey when compared to restaurants like it. We ate there once during our stay (there are so many amazing restaurants in SF you'll never eat at the same place twice), and while I don't really like Asian-Carribean fusion food, what they do they do very well. Not necessarily my taste, although an appetizer and martini is a great start to any night...The room service menu I thought was quite good. We ordered in a few times and the food arrived quickly, fresh from the kitchen, and was delicious.I could happily go on. I'll definitely return to the Clift next time I go to SF. No it's not an inexpensive hotel, but as always you get what you pay for and I was quite pleased with what I got. PARKING TIP - the 45 dollars a night they charge at the hotel is pretty much on par with other hotels in the area (it's the theater district so parking is naturally pricey). But if you're willing to go two blocks north on Geary there's a small garage on the right that charges 15/night, 20/night with in/out privaledges. It's literally a 2 minute walk to the hotel for those who want to save some money.

Jan 21 2007 	Business trip OK	The hotel itself was fine for one evening as I was there on business. The mattress was comfortable, and the room was clean and well put together.The concierge/front desk/ and doorman were very nice (I don't know if it's because I am a girl, or this is how it is normally).Bathroom was well stocked with the necessities and they had thick towels. Kudos on the bathroom. The lavender walls would have given me trouble on the eyes after a few days, if I was there longer.Room is a bit sparse for my personal taste, but if you love hip, modern hotels with homeless people walking in front, this is the place for you.Around the corner, there is an indian restaurant that does GREAT indian food.......(To the left, down 2 blocks and left, halfway down the street from the hotel's entrance).

Jan 11 2007 	Loved It	A bit late in posting this but had to respond to other comments! We travelled around California and finished our holiday at the Clift.I and my wife found the staff to be extremely helpful and friendly at all times,the rooms were comfortable and the bed fantastic!The Lobby design and atmosphere was excellent and the place was vibrant in the evenings.I wouldn't hesitate to return in the future...In fact I plan to

Jan 4 2007	Okay downstairs medicore room	Overrated and overpriced hotel. Downstairs is okay with too dimly lighted decor and elevator (are they trying to be more European style or just saving energy or from dusting?) Once you get to the hotel floor, it is totally different-- unflattering bright light with grey walls.Room is clean but somewhat small, great bed, tiny TV (not flat screen), delicious room service food. Nov 18 2006 	Total hype with bad service	This is the worst hotel I have stayed in. I have enjoyed Schrager hotels in NYC and London, but the Clift SF completely fell short of my expectations. The lobby and interior was hip, but the staff needs training in hotel management and good manners. The staff provided nothing but bad service to the point that I cut my stay short. This hotel attracts an obnoxious 20-something crowd looking for a drama/nighmare scene. I love hip hotels, but in a city that has so many great hotels, do yourself a favor and stay someplace else.

Nov 17 2006 	Another awesome stay	My boyfriend and I checked into the Clift for a weekend getaway and we had a fantastic time! The staff was incredibly friendly and thoughtful (I had mentioned to the bellman that this was a romantic getaway for us and next thing I know it - a couple of hours later we find a bottle of Champagne with a very sweet card from him in our room!). We loved our room and the decor and the bed is probably one of the most comfortable I have slept in. We hung out in the bar which had a really nice vibe to it and while we did not eat in the restaurant, we could see from our vantage point in the bar that it was hopping. Overall, it was a great experience and while the decor in itself is amazing, it was the staff that truly made our stay. Highly recommend it for anyone that is looking for a fun and exciting place to stay.

Nov 7 2006 	Overhyped	The public rooms in the hotel are beautiful but the bedrooms and bathrooms clearly have not had the same attention. The decor appeared more the result of one of those TV makeover shows than that of the revered Phillippe Starke. The bathroom was clearly an afterthought on the design front. The room was way too small to have a bath, which should ahve been ripped out and replaced with a decent shower unit.........a true design feature would have been a small wet room with a screen dividing the shower from the basin and toilet. The front-of-house staff were all very helpful and friendly. However, the waiting staff in the bar and restaurant leave a lot top be desired and clearly were employed for looks rather than ability (as is often the case in these designer hotels).I even took the drastic step of not leaving a tip, so disgusted was I with the wait for drinks and the inability to get it right first time.

Oct 31 2006 	Funky but...	The decor was cool. Very hip. The bar was awesome, and the staf f was very nice but... the reasonable rate rooms are very small. We could have lived with small, but the walls were very thin. We could hear everything in the next room. I mean everything. So- we asked to be moved thinking it was just that particular room. We had the same problem and the noice was even worse. So we had no choice but to upgrade. The room was much bigger, and we didn't hear anything next door (although we're not sure there was anyone next door). If you're looking for a romantic ,quiet ,hotel-- this is not it. Hip, fun,different-- sure this is the hotel.

Oct 27 2006 	Loved the Clift	I stayed at the Clift for the first time this past week for a business trip. The staff was fabulous -- everyone was friendly, helpful and very polished. In recent stays at some of the travel industry giants, the professionalism of the front desk staff, doormen, bellhops, etc. was quite poor, so this was very refreshing -- to use an analogy, it's akin to the marked the difference between the people behind the fast food counter at the airport and the people behind the desk in the Admiral's Club. The bar and restaurant are very nice, and they close the bar to external visitors on Wed nights, making it exclusive for hotel guests and their guests. This was nice, seeing as the prior three nights the bar had been packed -- while the "scene" was great those nights, it was nice to have it a bit more mellow too. The housekeeping was excellent -- my room was impeccable each time I returned. The doormen were great too -- as I was leaving the hotel, I realized I couldn't find my cellphone. Before I could even ask, one of them asked me what my phone number was so that they could help me find it. After I got home, I realized I'd forgotten to grab the copy of two fed ex airbills that I'd left with the concierge -- I called and he immediately offered to hunt down the info. He called back two minutes later with the tracking numbers and other info I needed. It was a refreshing change from the 20 min I usually spend on hold with customer service. It's the little courtesies like this that differentiate the great from the mediocre in my mind.. It's by far the most enjoyable business travel experience I've had this year. You can tell that this team takes a lot of pride in their work and really enjoys what they do for a living. I'd definitely stay there again the next time I'm in SF.

Oct 23 2006 	Excited about the Clift	Our stay at this posh boutique hotel was wonderful. We were greeted by a very pleasant front desk clerk who was able to check us into the hotel at 10am. The lobby, with its expansive fireplace, was very warm and inviting. The hotel which is a stones throw away from Union Square, is conveniently located near shops, restaurants and pubs. However, the Redwood Room Lounge had a delightful ambiance as did their fine dining restaurant, Cuba dAsia. If only the Clift had their own boutiques, there would be no reason to venture beyond their front doors. To sum it up, I found the Clift hotel to be a treasure trove of hospitality.

Oct 22 2006	Overrated	The staff was fantastic, and the room was very modern and bright. However, it was over $51 per day for parking($45 plus tax), and I felt that I was getting gauged. I received a fax, and I was charged a dollar per page for INCOMING faxes. It was only a few pages, but I just felt that they were figuring out ways to suck as much money out of me as possible. Also, the water pressure in the shower was great. The only problem was that there was a flimsy shower curtain that just blew around during my shower - wrapping around my leg and also permitting about a gallon of water to be on the bathroom floor. There is also no ventilation system in the bathroom, so everything in the bathroom becomes damp. I doubt that I would stay there again.

Oct 22 2006 	Good on an expense account--otherwise not worth it	I stayed at the Clift for 1 night this past April. It is similar to other hotels owned by this hotel group, with basic but tasteful furnishings, and an overall calm, zen feeling in the rooms. Even though the bathrrom was minimal (including a shower that was way too basic for the price of the room), I found the bed very comfortable and the night very relaxing. As it was a weekend night, the lobby was overrun a by loud, drunk, 20something crowd, most of whom were not hotel guests, and made getting in/out of the hotel a nightmare. In summary, the hotel is great if you want to party and are not paying for your own room, otherwise it is overpriced.

Oct 19 2006 	Clift in SF - the best!	If your travels take you to San Francisco you must stay at CLIFT! This hotel is so exclusive they don't even put the name on the outside. It's the 'who's who' and THE place to be seen in SF. We were treated like royalty from the first night. We did not have reservations in the famous Asia de Cuba restaurant (and heard you must make them weeks in advance), but they discreetly VIP'd us in anyway. The appetizers melt in your mouth and the dinner was to die for. Inside the Redwood Room (bar area), everybody is gorgeous - I swear the hotel must pay professional models to drink there. A sight to behold. The women are beautiful and the men, (ALL men older and younger) are handsome, flirtatious and classy. I enjoyed watching the pictures on the wall. The eyes move and a silent soap opera is going on-if you have time to watch. The rooms inside the hotel are very, very modern and the bed made me feel like I was on a cloud. The staff is very down to earth, very professional, and treated me like a VIP the entire time. CLIFT is so SF (is on the same street as the theatres and 1 blk from Union Square) you will miss out if you miss this gem in the city by the bay.

Oct 9 2006	All mouth no trousers	Just back from a week at the Clift. Sep 17 2006 	Clift: Great Bar and Ground Floor But Improve Service Focus!	This is a funky Boutique Hotel aimed at a younger (or young at heart) audience which appreciates the contemporary vibe. I am a frequent traveller and have stayed in St. Martin's Lane, the sister hotel in London.I was really excited about my stay at the Clift, and got a deal via travelzoo, booking on the hotel website for $244/night. Regular rooms were as low as $175 including breakfast.GOOD POINTSGreat location two minutes walk from Union Square, and very helpful Concierge. Lovely reception area decor. Superb Redwoom Room bar. In my room sheets were superb quality, air conditioning worked brillianty and housekeeping was efficient (if noisy in the morning). Spacious deluxe room (333) had two beds and plenty of bathroom space, albeit a 1970s low-style flat backed tub.LESS GOOD POINTSFIRST Check in experience was poor; new trainee was trying very hard and was professional, but should have had closer more dedicated supervision from his manager, and she was not able to dedicate enough time to supporting him, this meant he was made to look incompetent, which must have been unsettling to him and not ideal for me the customer either (it took nearly ten minutes to check me in on a simple reservation).He told us our room category was overbooked, and we were being upgraded to a larger room on a high floor. Yippee we thought. Then I noticed we were being checked into a standard room; when I brought this to his attention we were found the paid for Deluxe Room, but on the very low third floor.SECOND, the mattress support slats under the bed in my room had fallen out meaning the mattress was unsupported and uneven; I understand these things happen and when I raised it with the front desk when I realised the next morning after a poor night's sleep it was dealt with BUT the response was simply "we'll deal with it" rather than demonstrating concern that I may have had an uncomfortable night's sleep. I must stress I was NOT looking for any compensation here. But more of an apology/concern should have been demonstrated by the front desk person at a five star hotel. Maybe this is a cultural thing, but "sorry" goes a long way.This was a minor insignificant issue for me, but other may not have had the energy to check what the problem with the bed was (the mattress was heavy to lift up!) and a verbal apology should accompany any complaint.THIRD Housekeeping started asking if rooms were free at 0830am by knocking and announcing "housekeeping" loudly - surely a more efficient system could be established to avoid waking your many international guests who are on a different tmie zone, and a clearer encouragement to guests to use the Privacy Please door guards to avoid this unwanted noise?FOURTH noise from the street. This is an urban location, and frankly those who complain need to get over it. By the time the traffic gets going you should be out there enjoying the sights!FINALLY, my rate booked on the Morgans site included breakfast but this was not noted in my reservation and I only received this paid for benefit by having the foresight to print out the reservation at the time of booking and was made to present this to the frontdesk. Your reservation system needs to ensure all special offer benefits are noted in detail in the reservation. Same thing happened when I stayed in St Martins Lane so this is a systemic problem.I stay about 50 hotel nights a year for business and pleasure, and had a superb stay at St Martin's Lane earlier in the year, but my experience at the Clift was mixed, which was a disappointment, and most of these problems noted above are "soft" people skill or process change issues which should easily be fixed with management attention.I tried submitting this via the email link I was sent after my stay, but once I had filled out all the data, the site crashed when I submitted it - a great idea but again you need to follow up on the detail.I expect high standards from such a five star hotel, and my review is therefore somewhat picky, but I hope fair given the prices some people pay for rooms here.VERDICT: What would have been an awesome stay was made less so by poor management of trainees, a lack of empathy from the front desk, noisy housekeeping and problems with ensuring guest entitlements are captured when making the reservation online.

Sep 2 2006 	Needs to focus on the basics	My wife and I got this hotel through a Priceline four star hotel "name your own price deal" although it still worked out as one of the most expensive of the nine places we stayed on in our visit to the States. I personally found the door and desk staff to be polite and helpful. The hotel and our room was clean and comfortable, with a nice bed. They gym was generally very well maintained and well equipped, although a cross-training machine would be a good addition. The location was convenient for the Union Square area.We found the decor a bit off-the-wall, and even quite funny, in some places (the bizarre collection of chairs in reception; the neon lighting in the lifts; the obsession with mirrors and curtains in the room). But this is ultimately a matter of personal taste, and its good to see a hotel trying to do something a bit different in this regard. However, this minimalist "style" comes at the cost of functionality. Our bathroom (see photo) was tiny. The room itself was by far the smallest of the nine hotels we stayed in, and storage space was one small closet (see photo). I'm over 6 feet tall but I still had to stand on a chair to use the room safe. Despite the lack of other storage options, the bedside table was just a big transparent block (see photo). The radio alarm clock was so complicated that we couldn't use it. We eventually gave up and I set the alarm on my phone instead. The TV was small, but big enough for such a small room.I cant understand why the Clift doesnt put a proper sign up. Aside from the inconvenience to customers who have pre-booked, they must miss out on passing trade. There is a sign, but it took me two days to spot it.We didn't use room service, but we noticed that it would have been subject to no less than three separate charges (something like a service charge, a delivery charge and a gratuity). Im pleased to see the hotel management are monitoring this site. If the coolness and pretentiousness was toned down a bit, and the focus was moved towards improving the guest experience, this could be a reasonable hotel, although the room size issue remains a problem. That said, I'm not really bothered about whether a hotel maintains its "avant garde vibe", so I'm probably not the real target audience. My wife described the Clift as "trying to be pretentious" which just about summed it up for me.

Jul 27 2006	shame the hotel wasnt as good as the restaurant!	we arrived at the clift late afternoon to find we had to struggle in with our own luggage (3 bags!) the reception staff were very unhelpful and uninterested. we eventually managed to get everything sorted and were shown up to our room on the 9th floor. the room was a 'junior suite' and they tried to make out we had a separate living room by putting a curtain inbetween the bedroom and the living room!! the bathroom was tiny and dirty. i stayed here with my mum and unfortunatley on the first night she didnt feel well and had been suffering from a bad foot. she decided to phone down to reception to ask if there was a doctor that would come to the hotel only to be told ther wasnt one local however the receptionist 'put her through' to the closest one and she was told to phone someone else. we eventually decided to go to the hospital just to be safe. when we came back from the hospital that evening the doormen were talking to some girls outside and we had to let ourselves in! Mar 20 2006 	Nice Place to Visit But...	Probably one of the most overrated hotels I've ever stayed in -- the Clift makes a great "E!" Network backdrop but is overpriced, impractical, and thinks it's way cooler than it is.I've never felt insulted and ignored in a restaurant while ordering a $40 breakfast before, but there's a first time for everything, and the Clift's Asia de Cuba definitely delivered on the "you're not cool enough to be here" theme. The guest room looks like something out of architectural digest -- great in pictures, but not so great for real human beings. If your idea of fun is trying to figure out how to work the lights in your room, or guess where the hair dryer is, the Clift is for you -- design definitely trumps usability in this hotel.This isn't to say The Clift doesn't have anything going for it; the bar is swanky and entertaining, and I've eaten at the Asia de Cuba at the Mondrian in LA, and the food there was good. But the Clift is one of those hotels that makes a better side trip than a principal destination. My advice: stay at the Hotel Monaco next door, and journey over to the Clift one night for drinks. The Monaco offers complimentary wine and cheese, massages, ethernet, and workout room, and its restaurant is a lot more down to earth. The Clift offers complimentary attitude, and charges you a premium for the privilege.

Feb 17 2006	Escape to an exciting hotel! Feb 9 2006 	Repeat guest and loving it!	We visit this hotel almost every month because we are addicted to the San Francisco atmosphere. Oct 18 2005	Great designer hotel****	I loved that hotel. It's a great city designer hotel. Oct 1 2005 	Overall a nice a hotel	Ok, I have mixed feelings about The Clift...first of all it's not well marked from the street and as a vistor in SFO, trying to navigate the streets you fly right past it...but after you walk through the cool lobby with its dark wood and bar area, you will either say Wow this is cool or Oh no, this is not for me...I loved the ambiance of the clift....The beds were great, my room was nice/spacious(both rooms), the gym is small, the front desk is forgetful and the doormen are well...nice to look at! Anyway, I went out to SFO early, spending the weekend before a conference doing the 17 mile drive and Napa day trips. Because of my day trips I arrived late to the hotel, after 9pm. With this in mind I called the hotel to let them know to hold my non smoking king room...I will be checking in late. Of course when I got to the hotel on my first night, I was given the key to a double bed, smoking room. I was upset but jet lagged and tired so, with promises that they will change my room tomorrow, I went to bed. We were visting Napa and leaving early the next morning so I called to inquire about the move and they told me to pack and they would move me...and when I got in that night just stop by the desk and pick up my new room key. Well you know what happened...when I got in from Napa, I met blank stares at the front desk about my move. After about 10 mins a decision was made to upgrade me to a suite...Hey that suited me just fine...There was really no other decision they could make after 2 mistakes. The location is Great, the drinks are great, the atmosphere is cool if not a little snobby but smile and they will smile with you. If you want to stay at a happening, sophisticated place then the Clift is for you. One last thing, have breakfast at Max's 1 block down. Great food!

Sep 13 2005	Wonderful if you get a deal and use some helpful hints	I was very pleased with my experience at the Clift, although I am glad I read this website before getting there. The room was pleasant and clean. The bed and linens were so comfortable. And the staff was extremely pleasant and helpful.Firstly, my husband and I arrived at the hotel at 9:30 in the morning, and they let us check in early (no added fee). Our bellman chatted with us the entire way up about cool places to go and see while in town. And when we wanted directions to drive to Muir Woods, they already had them printed out and found them for us very quickly. For people who were dissatisfied with their visit, I think you have to know what you are getting into. This is a hip, trendy spot that caters to people who fancy themselves as hip and trendy. This is NOT a family oriented place where you spend the afternoon with your kids hanging out by the pool.That being said, the picetag for this hotel is slightly excessive... we got a deal through orbitz where our room ended up costing about $150/night for a 3 night stay (fri to mon), and I would have been annoyed if we had paid full price for the stay. Also, the bahroom is small, but as my husband and I are pretty thin and short, so it didn't bother us at all.Some helpful tips:1. Ask for an interior or courtyard room. We did, and they were happy to oblige us with one on the 4th floor... we heard NO traffic noise.2. Don't park here if you can help it... it is overpriced! We rode the BART into town and walked the few blocks to the hotel, then rented a car only for the day we needed it at Enterprise at the Nikko Hotel (about 3 short blocks away) for $25/day and returned it the same day so we didn't need to pay for parking. Alternatively, there is a lot 1/2 a block down the street on Taylor where they'll park your car for $18 overnight.3. The hotel restaurant is also overpriced... skip it and try Scala's Bistro at the Sir Francis Drake hotel on Powell. The meals at Scala's excellent in quality. The portion size is perfect (NOT huge so there is room for dessert). 4. Place the Do Not Disturb tag on your doorknob if you want to sleep in. The cleaning crew are serious about their business and came around at 8am to check the room, and again at 9am to see if we were gone so that they could clean the room.5. $10 for ethernet connection?!??!?!? You can walk to union square and use the free wi-fi while sitting outside and enjoying the park.

Sep 9 2005 	loved the experience	Definitely will stay at this hotel again next time. A bit pricy but worth it.. Staffs were helpful and kind. Beautiful room. Nice location.. Make sure you have breakfast at Taylor street coffee shop a block down the taylor street.
