Jul 18 2005	nice hotel excellent location	first let me start by thanking the previous reviewers who noted that the hotel is completely umarked from the street, if they hadnt said that i would have driven around for ever looking for it. now on to the actual review. when in sf i usually stay at the hilton that is near the cliff but i got an excellent deal on the clift so i decided to give it a try. the clift is a nice hotel, the location is excellent, close to union square and market st. the room was decent sized and bright a furnished in a very "ikea-esque" way. the staff was curteous and friendly. all in all, a nice hotel, i dont think i would pay full price there but if you can get a good deal there, then by all means go for it.

The bar scene is the best in town and the staff was very helpful. I would definetly stay at the Clift again.

Mar 14 2005	great decor	My husband and I stayed there for a night and the room was very nice. The bed was very comfortable we slept very good that night. Mar 11 2005 	The hotel was nice but not up to 5 star snuff	Everyone at the Clift was great and the decore was nice. The bathroom was so small, though, and there wasn't much place to put things. They need to fine tune....

Jan 21 2005	Excellent	It's a scene, but isn't that what you expect when staying at one of Ian's hotels? The service was excellent and the location is conveniently in the middle of everything. The decor is beautiful yet edgy. Overall, it was a pleasurable experience.

Jan 15 2005	very hip decor okay staff	Locating the Clift is particularly perilous at night with all those one-way streets because the only distinguishing markers are purple windows (luckily, I remembered this from the website photos). The very hip decor is interesting (antlers on furniture, oversized chairs, animal skins, etc.), though one might be afraid that sitting on the furniture would elicit critical looks from the staff. Checking in was somewhat cumbersome due to a computer glitch, but was otherwise fine. Our room was a decent size and overlooked the street below where noise carried very well. A pity since we were staying when hotel employees were picketing outside several other hotels in the area beginning at 6 a.m. until 6 p.m. (check to see if there are still labor disputes and at which hotels). The furniture comes in light colors (white, cream, lilac, and melon) and some aren't entirely functional, like the orange plastic bedside "tables" that would be more useful as stepping stools. However, I do appreciate hotel design and the room was tastefully done with very clean lines, smooth textures, and solid colors. It was particularly beautiful in the morning with the sun in full force. Beware, though, that the bathrooms are indeed very small and less functional than they should be. A large mirror blankets one wall and there is a teeny wastebasket underneath the table beneath the sink. I felt so untidy because there were no drawers to contain my toiletries, which, as a result, kept rolling everywhere. The mini-bar is well-stocked with useful items that come at a hefty price (as in any hotel). The walls are so thin that I could hear my neighbor watch TV ALL night. The fitness center was much smaller than I expected, but very clean and well-equipped. The concierge was very helpful in locating a great restaurant at the last minute. The hotel really is located in the center of downtown San Francisco, making it easy to walk to Union Square, the MOMA, and other attractions. I'm from Los Angeles where I've eaten at the Asia de Cuba in the Mondrian (beautiful restaurant by the way), so I wasn't interested in dining at Asia de Cuba in the Clift. I did spot it through the glass in the Redwood Room, where you should reserve a table well in advance since standing in a tight space isn't much fun. The room is beautiful, although the LCD displays are a little eery. When returning from a late night out on a weekend, someone will probably ask to see your guest card before admitting you through the door. I actually think it's a good idea for security reasons. Overall, the staff was friendly, although a bit aloof in certain instances. The hotel is very clean and nothing is dated, for better or worse. I saw people of all ages lounging about in the public spaces. I would stay again for a partying occassion, but I don't consider it a particularly romantic hotel.

Jan 9 2005 	Trendy but comfortable	Hey, it's an Ian Schraeger hotel. There's going to be lots of cool oversized furniture, moody lighting, and the most attractive staff in town. If that bugs you then this is not your hotel. For the rest of you, the bed and the bedding are great. The bathrooms are nicely updated. The staff is extremely helpful and courteous. Room service, the restraunt, and the bar are fabulous. There are a million pay per view movies and in room tv internet service. I think this is a great place to stay for work or pleasure. Especially if you can get a good rate.

Jan 5 2005	Not your traditional hotel experience	This hotel was an "experience." We stayed at this hotel with a wedding party and paid around $190/night. We thought the rates fair for a high class hotel and comparable with others in SF area. We stayed in a standard room and the bride & groom were in a high-end suite so we got to experience both. The decor of the rooms is minimal and modern. White sheets and duvets with splashes of color using pillow throws, mirrors, and plexi-galss. Bathroom was small, but well appointed and clean. We liked staying here, but they are definitely snooty. There is no sign on the hotel itself, and when asked, the doormen harp on the "exclusivity" of the hotel. And even though we requested a table reservation at the bar for the wedding party, we did not have one when we arrived and when we finally got one, we were asked to move after 30 minutes. And the drinks are ridiculously priced. Overall, we enjoyed staying there depsite the snootiness, but might try a more reasonably priced hotel next time.

Jan 4 2005	Hip trendy comfortable clean and in the center of everything!	I have stayed at the Clift twice and both times had a pleasurable experience. Jan 3 2005	Superb except Asia	Arrived as part of our Honeymoon world tour at Christmas\04. The Clift definitely compares well with other 5 star hotels we stayed in. Dec 15 2004	Clift Hotel	Nice Hotel but overpriced.If you have a query about your bill make sure that you get an ammended and printed copy of your bill before you leave

Dec 10 2004	Do not stay	Tiny Rooms..Bathrooms the size of the closet...MOST OF ALL...my wife and I were asked to not sit on a particular couch, and "Could we move to the seating over there"?????? Nov 11 2004	Fabulous	I read all these bad reviews of the Clift before my trip and was apprehensive about my stay there but as it appears, people are more vocal when they are upset with a place. That's why I feel as if I need to put in my two cents. My boyfriend and I stayed there for four nights from Nov 3-7, 2004. Yes, it's true--no iron, no dresser, no fridge etc. But I've also stayed at the Hudson and it's the same situation. I think they did a great job with the amount of space they were given. And yes, the minibar is expensive, but there are 5 liquor stores within a block radius of the hotel, AND a pharmacy across the street. Not to mention the Redwood Room downstairs. (They make the best martinis).The rooms were trendy. Delicious bed---super fluffy pillows and cozy down comforters. Minimalistic furniture, curtains framing all four walls, and oh my god! There are mirrors, I'm talking floor to ceiling, on two opposing walls of the rooms so every morning I would wake up to 10 of me staring back. We couldn't help but put on a show for ourselves with a treat like that.And the staff was not snobby, like I had read. They were VERY VERY helpful and courteous. They weren' t judgemental, even when I walked in with TAKE-OUT food or snacks for the room. People of all ages would hang out in the lobby and bar area, not just San Francisco's hip and superficial. And there IS signage on the hotel. It's all the way on top of the building. You just need to look up. I know I'm getting technical, but I need to defend the CLIFT. All these people that write to say that there's no sign *wah wah wah* were too occupied looking at their feet to see it. Anyway, I had a great time. The service was wonderful. Turndown service every night. Not a hotel choice for you if you're on your honeymoon and trying to force romantic moments every second of the day.

Nov 4 2004	Too trendy pour moi	We stayed for two nights at either end of our honeymoon to Hawaii in October. The Clift is definitely for the young trend setter who wants to be seen staying at the trendy hotels. The entrance is difficult to locate as there is no name to indicate that its the Clift from the front. On entrance to the reception is very modern and dark, which initially I liked but trying to check in in this light is a bit difficult. I felt you needed a torch to find your way around in the lobby area. The staff were very friendly and were extremely helpful.The rooms are ultra modern again and furniture is sparse. Rooms are small and the bathrooms are tiny. Sitting on the loo you had the toilet roll up on top of you!! Again, disappointed that no tea/coffee facilities in the room, plus our safe didn't work either. Mini bar extremely expensive and they even charged for the little sewing kits that hotels normally provide.Walls are thin so if you got noisy neighbours, your in trouble. On our second night, our room was a connecting room and luckily our neighbours didn't stay up too late but when they were having breakfast the next day you could practically hear them chewing. Definitely not my cup of tea but if I was a younger hip person, would probably love it!

Oct 22 2004 	Trying too hard to be cool	The once glorious Clift is now another attempt from the Morgan's group at being "cool."Outrageously expensive from the mini-bar to the room rates, the rooms feature walls that are about 70 percent mirrored. This ultra-glassed-in feature is most unappealing in earthquake-prone San Francisco. Staff has major attitude and there are no irons, ironing boards or coffee pots in rooms.The beds are ok but the other furniture is uncomfortable and uninviting - if you are into Feng Shui, forget it - with mirrors and "shars" everywhere you will suffer nightmares as I did.There are scores of better deals for your 300 dollars a night in San Francisco than this dreary replay of a Morgan's group jail cell.

Oct 3 2004	The "Old Clift" was much nicer	We stayed at the Clift for three nights this summer (July 23 - 26, 2004). My wife and I had often stayed at the old Clift Hotel before it was taken over and renovated by the Ian Schrager group. The old Clift may have been showing its age, but it had spacious, elegantly furnished rooms in a convenient part of town. What a disappointment it was to see what has been done to this once great hotel ! We booked an Studio Jr. Suite which was described as an "L" shaped room. We quickly discovered that this was one of the former spacious rooms from the old Clift that we remembered so fondly, but it had been chopped up into two rooms ... creating a window-less bedroom area and very cramped sitting area. The decor makes abundant use of petroleum based synthetic materials (think plastic draperies, plastic night stands & tables, plastic covered furnitiure) and has most opposing walls covered floor to ceiling with tinted mirrors. The mirrors tend to give the room a subtle feeling of nausea and the hard bench type furniture was uncomfortable. The bedding was of good quality but they must have contracted with a lumber company for the mattresses. My wife was particularly disappointed in the bathroom. It was cramped, with barely enough room for one person to turn around. There was no counter space and even the tub was scaled down to fit in such a small space. The old Clift had spacious, well appointed, marble bathrooms.The lobby and public areas have very dim lighting, which seemed stylish and attractive at first, but then became annoying. The elevator compartment was so darkened you could not even see the person standing next to you.They have even ruined the famous Redwood Room Bar. All of the warmth and intimacy of the old Redwood Room is missing, replaced by garish lighting and hard, uninviting bench type seats. The hostess greeted us at entrace with "Oh .. are you here to inquire about reservations?". Acutally, we just wanted a glass of wine before going to dinner, but after seeing what has been done to the ambiance, I was almost in tears.Unless you are attacted to dark spaces and synthetic materials, I would give this hotel a pass. We certainly will not be back.

Sep 28 2004	Cool and trendy and too plain	Very cool place!!! The windows outside are beautiful, and the inside rockas as well...unfortunately, the rooms suck!!! Sep 12 2004 	The Clift Hotel: For those who aspire to be rich and cool	but haven't quite achieved either goal. For genuine class, pampering and good hospitality, stay elsewhere. We stayed at The Clift Hotel on the basis of enjoying a drink in the Redwood Room on a previous trip to San Francisco. We are a young couple who like to dress up and we thought the bar and lobby was attractively hip. Hipper than thou as it turns out and sadly, the residential experience was completely underwhelming. Although the room was pretty enough with its diaphanous cream curtains and pale birch furniture, it was marred by stained carpets and a musty smell. The bathroom was unbelievably tiny and although I am slim, I ended up with a bruise on my thigh from from bumping against the door, which stupidly opens inward into this already small space. Also, there is no surface area for toiletries, which I guess is fine if all you travel with is your toothbrush.We were irritated by the fee for highspeed internet access and the absence of a coffee maker, the latter being a basic necessity that you could find at any 1 star motel. A further annoyance was the prominent exhibition in the room of a number of of exhorbitantly priced items for sale.Our maid was nice and friendly and the concierge was fine, but the rest of the staff were too young, unprofessional and overly concerned with posing to fully focus on the needs of guests and create a luxurious atmosphere. Although hotel workers are human beings with their own private life, that's where it should remain - private. While waiting by the front desk for the return of an item from housekeeping, I don't want to hear the receptionists chatting about their previous night's partying and how they didn't get to bed until 6 in the morning. The prices in the Redwood Room and the adjoining restaurant are terribly inflated and although the food is nice, it is not outstanding and simply not worth the money. My husband and I enjoy good things but neither of us like to be ripped off and with The Clift Hotel, you feel you are at every turn. After 3 days we moved out and checked into The Monaco next door which is where we stayed last time and is just exquisite (see the reviews here on Tripadvisor).There is nothing majorly wrong with this hotel but for the money you can do so much better. Definitely call into the Redwood Room for a pre dinner cocktail and to admire the video installations, but stay somewhere else.

Sep 3 2004	Failed to meet expectations	The Clift hotel failed to meet my expectations and is was a major dissappointment. It is definitely not a five star hotel. The general unwelcome feel one experiences upon entering the lobby is compounded by the arrogant pushy attitudes of the door staff, front desk staff, and especially the cranky concierge. They don't have a pool, there's a pungent smell on most of the floors, and you have to pay for using the internet. The hotel is dimly lighted so that visitors can't see the worn and stained carpet. The hotel becomes infested with nightclubbers at night with all these cheezy types acting like monkeys on the lobby furniture as well as keeping ourselves and the other guests annoyed with their techno music blasting from the spanish suite right next door. And then there's the hotel bar, the Redwood Room. I don't mind paying more for a fine modern bar experience but again the Clift has failed in this department. The bar is very attractive and stylish, blending the history of the old grande hotel with the modern elements in a silky smooth collage. That's where the positives end - great design, poor execution. On approaching the hostess stand guests are looked up and down before being escorted to an appropriate location. Interestingly, the more attractive the look, the more prominent the location will be. We were seated right at the bar. The sharp looking bartenders were standing around chatting and didn't notice our deep need for a drink for quite some time. On approach, I asked what their signature cocktail was. The bartender responded by asking what I usually drink (a Chopin Martini), walked away, made the drink, presented it, and said, that'll be $14. Then he asked my colleague what she wanted to drink. She opted for a bottle of becks. $8. That was our last visit to that bar.

Aug 13 2004	Wonderland for the Jetset	The Clift web site says the hotel is "a wonderland for the jetset." It's true. I stay there often just to add some fun to business trips. So, heres a test to help you decide if Clift is right for you:Stay at Clift if:You think its cool its a stealth hotel (no sign or name on building)You can speak at least two languages (required to be truly jetset)You know Prada from DKNYYou collect frequent flyer miles on 14 different airlinesYou are willing to over look minor problems with the staff simply because they are very good lookingYou are willing to pay $15 a drink so that you can lounge in a beautiful room full of beautiful people.You have an expense accout or trust fundThe thought of owning a minivan makes your skin crawl Do NOT stay at Clift:You think its totally absurd that the hotel has no signYou are a retired librarian looking for a peaceful place to sleep and read.You are fashion-challenged (you know who you are)You collect Precious Moments figurinesYou cannot handle a bit of friendly attitude from the staff and other guestsYou find yourself asking, Who is Philippe Starck?You are on a budgetYou own a minivan

Jul 30 2004 	If image is all that matters to you...	Your first clue is the lack of signage. The Clift is far too trendy to identify its location by anything so common as a nameplate visible from the street.The valet parking staff is friendly, though, assuming you can find a place for your car on the crowded curb in front of the hotel. Plan on a hefty $40 per night for valet parking.Once inside, the clever theatricality of the lobby, dining room and bar make the efforts to arrive seem worthwhile. Check-in is efficient, if not exactly friendly or welcoming.A warning, though. If you get a room with a pass-through door to the room adjacent, immediately return to the front desk and ask for or pay for a room with solid walls. I did not and my neighbors stayed up all night long playing music and entertaining guests. Despite a call from the manager at 12:30 PM and a call from myself at 3 AM, the noise continued unabated till 4:30 AM, leaving me no recourse but to spend a very early morning in the lobby. Why the lobby? Well, the night staff informed me that while they were sorry, they could not give me another room until the morning manager arrived. Three hours later he did arrive and did give me another room. According to the bell staff, there were ample empty rooms. Apparently due to my group rate, the night staff wasn't "authorized" to give me another room. In effect, their rules were far more important than my comfort or inconvience. So...no sleep at all at this 4-star hotel the first night.The next night of my four-night stay, a friend and I decided to investigate the bar. The hostess condescended to find us a table and with a great deal of attitude announced that we might have one in a few minutes - depending on how long we were staying!We decided we weren't nearly important enough to enjoy the gloomy darkness and thumpa-wumpa music of the bar at the Clift, so we crossed the street and discovered the delightful Cafe Grand at the equally delightful Hotel Monaco. Evidently Kimpton hotels regard guests as valued friends and Schrager properties - like the ever-so-precious Clift - do not. Unless you share the attitude, of course, and enjoy trading superior glances with the staff.I'll give the Clift ample stars for design and poseur-power. But as a fine hotel...truly, they have a lot to learn about hospitality.

Jul 21 2004	Unique Hotel	This comment from a previous review was what sparked our interest in the Clift: "I would not recommend this hotel for families. On the weekend it is very similar to staying at a night club." The reviewer was absolutely correct. If you're planning to bring the kids to San Francisco, you may want to stay at the Hampton Inn instead. The decor at the Clift is minimalist yet fun and creative...definitely has a night-clubbish feel. The service was excellent and very friendly; we didn't experience the attitude and snobbishness mentioned in previous reviews. The sleigh bed was SO comfortable, we loved the luxury linens. Our corner room was surprisingly spacious. The hotel location was convenient. The only complaints we had were, the bathroom seemed somewhat small and valet parking seemed a little pricey. Other than that, we would definitely stay at the Clift next time we're in town!

May 1 2004	Terrific service Great location	We had read not-so-favorable reviews of the staff in terms of friendliness and were concerned prior to arrival. The concerns were unfounded. The service was excellent and the staff incredibly friendly. It's a fun place to stay in a great location - walking distance of China Town and Union Square shopping

Apr 5 2004	For something fun and different...	This place doesn't have to try too hard to be ultra hip or cool. The fact that the hotel doesn't even have to put a sign on the building or the door will tell you that. With that being said, a stay at the Clift can transport you to a hip and trendy city lifestyle, which is exactly what I wanted for a weekend getaway from suburbia. The rooms are clean, light, and tastefully decorated in a very modern style; very comfy sleigh bed with superior down and cotton bedding. I'm pretty picky about my sheets, and I was tempted to buy these to take home with me. The hotel has the bedding custom made for them and new sets are available for sale. A stay at the Clift can be pricey. This is a trendy five-star hotel after all. However, packages can be found with good discounts for people not wanting regular chain-like accomodations and adventurous to try something different. I opted for a deluxe room at the Clift and was glad I did. There were three large windows in my outside facing corner room allowing lots of light and pleasant city sounds to filter in. The Clift's location is not ideal for sweeping views; but this was acceptable with me when selecting the hotel. A nice touch to the decor of the room were the mirrors and floor to ceiling curtains adorning the walls. No need for artwork that way, just the pleasant mix of colors, fabrics, glass, and contemporary furniture. Is the decor what I might select for my home? Probably not, but the change of scenery sure was fun for a evening. The room had candles and matches ready to go and the warm indirect lighting helped make this a contemporary romantic getaway. The CD player had excellent sound and the DVD player was a nice touch. Some might find the tv a joke as it's only a 19" model, but then again, I wasn't shelling out big bucks for watching tv. The location of the Clift is excellent for the theatre/shopping crowd and getting a cab is not too difficult. The front desk staff and the doormen were very friendly and helpful. The only thing keeping this stay from being an excellent experience was the breakfast at the Asia De Cuba restaurant. The decor and the food are nice, but they must have been understaffed the morning I decided to go, although the restaurant was not even 25% full. Breakfast was included with my special package rate, so this is where I was going to dine no matter what, but I expected decent, if not excellent and courteous service at such a fine restaurant. I could barely get a refill on my iced tea. The table next to mine was getting very impatient and almost downright rude about the slow service. All in all, I would steer clear of breakfast, unless it's included in your rate. Reviews for lunch and dinner seem to be better...so maybe someday I'll check it out, but with so many other choices in the city, the Asia De Cuba left a bad impression on me and it will be some time before I return to eat there. Some people leaving reviews have complained about noise, smelling smoke in the hallways, and having no dresser in the room, but I did not encounter any problem with these. I found the closet adequate for my luggage and unpacking of my necessary items so as to reduce wrinkling. As for noise, this is the CITY, not a country getaway, so I anticipated I'd hear some noise at some point in my stay, but honestly, I was never disrupted by noise in any way. I definitely rate the hotel very high in terms of a nice stay and felt I had a good value for my money.

Apr 1 2004	Wow! Clift is on a come back!	I had not been to Cift in about 6 months. I was up this Saturday for the night and WOW... The service blew me away. There were smiles everywhere. Every single staff person flashed me a smile and endulged my need for fun conversation. Lets face it, it has always been a cool place... but hey... San Francisco is not NYC and not Los Angeles. In San Francisco... we are all beautiful people.. and we want to be treated as such. Clift Staff have recieved the message and are delivering. Bravo... I will so be back!We ate at Cuba de Asia. Oh my gosh... The meal was incredible. We had my goddaughter with us and she is an angel... If she wasn't... I would never have taken her to this kind of restaurant. The staff went way out to make all of us feel like we were royalty. (Its not a kid place but this kid is kind of special). Our waiter Sean, I don't even know what to say. He knew every detail, spice, food texture. He was on the money! He knew when to be there and when to stay away. His recommendations were right on. He was honest, handsome, and so professional. We wanted to take him home. After dinner it was the Redwood Room. If you haven't been there, go. It is expensive but once again, the drinks are fantastic and the atomosphere.... energizing. The staff in the Redwood Room, Bar None (no pun intended), are about as good as it gets. Something is going on because the gang at Clift have seen the San Francisco Light. No more attitude here. The staff are fashionable, smart, and quite frankly cool. They went way out of their way to treat us well, make our evening fun... right down to the manager who checked in to make sure we were having a great night. The staff are still beautiful... but they make you feel the same. Something is alive and well at Clift. Stop by and check it out... you won't be sorry.

Great for people watching and partying.

Jan 9 2004	perfect hip hotel...incredible room	i stayed 3 nights at Clift in early september and was very pleased. i was checking in late, around 7 pm, so was surprised when the desk agent said the room was not yet clean, and would be about 30 minutes. i was meeting freinds for dinner and didn't relish a wait in the lobby. the agent said that he could offer me another room that was ready immeadiately, but that this was a special room and would be worth the wait....i waited.....it was AMAZING. on the top floor corner (#1701). a little odd because the elevator only goes to 16, then you have to go up a little curving staircase to 17. a huge corner room with a little entryway with a floor to ceiling curtain, very high ceilings, large panorama windows on both sides with incredible city views, a wet bar with sink, large dressing room and a windowed bathroom. get this room if at all possible. every staff member from bell boys to room service remarked that this is their favorite room. not a bad price for a room like this either. i found all the staff very freindly and helpful from front desk to valet to very informative concierge. room had internet TV with wireless keyboard which was a nice touch. fantastic lighting, fabrics, furniture. all up to par with the style and professionalism of schrager hotels. used the gym which was perfect. modern treadmills with tv's. redwood room and asia de cuba are always a scene if you want that. great location near union square. this room certainly made the stay at Clift a pleasure. not sure what the comments are in other reviews about it not really being a 5 star hotel. if they are looking for a classic 5 star experience, go to the four seasons or the carlyle. schrager hotels are consistently very clean, very well put together and comfortable and stylish and efficient and lots of fun to stay in. always worth the money in my book. perhaps not the right fit for an older timid crowd that's not looking for or expecting this experience. i enjoyed it very much.

Jan 4 2004	STAY AWAY! RUDE! CROOKED HOTEL! AWFUL!	The Clift Hotel is a piece of trash! The idiot doorman at the front would rather scratch his head than help you get your bags. The facilities were absolutely abyssmal.Avoid this hotel and save your money. Go anywhere else.

Dec 5 2003	Not Quite 5 Star	Though my stay at the Clift was most delightful, I was surprised at the absence of luxury in some of the amenities and services. The quality of the towels and robes, for example, were not quite up to par for a 5-star hotel. Not exactly the softest Egyptian cotton. The bathroom was also so small that I could barely open the door to get out of it. The service at the restaurant and bar was also a bit lackluster -- I waited over 15 minutes in the main bar before anyone came to take my order. However, all of the door men and front desk clerks were extremely helpful and friendly. Plus, the dark lighting and rich fabrics of the lobby provided a great end of the day escape from work.

Nov 17 2003	Great Time	An excellent hotel with top notch service. It is a welcome respite from a busy day in the city, both the lobby lounge and the rooms are incredibly comfortable and the staff is welcoming. A great choice for travelers looking for a hip, progressive, yet friendly hotel.

Nov 14 2003	Stay Away!	My husband and I booked our stay through Expedia - I guess the Clift keeps its "real" rooms for guests paying full price. We could hear EVERYTHING from the next room (snoring, T.V., phone conversations, etc...). Not at all impressed. We've stayed at some pretty high-end, 5-star hotels and the Clift definitely wasn't one of them. We were not impressed with the hotel staff - I guess they're underpaid.Stay away.

Nov 9 2003	Worthless	I usually stay at Campton Place but decided to give the Clift a try for a change of scenery. The service was not up to the level that it should be for a hotel that purports to be of such a high level. The rooms were decent. The food was bad. There wasn't an available porter to take my bags. The concierge gave me inaccurate information and I missed breakfast. I wouldn't go back. I'll return to Campton Place where the level of service is high and the food is great.

Nov 8 2003	Stylish and reasonable	I have to base this review on the price we paid because I think we got a cracking deal only paying $140 a night for 4 nights. This place is ultra cool, the rooms are not huge but beautifully designed as is the entire hotel. Ignore the review that says you can park in SF for $10 as the going rate for overnight is about $29 so whilst $40 for valet parking is not cheap it isn't exhorbitant by SF standards. The hotel is great for Union Square with just a 5 minute walk on the flat (unusual for SF) and it has a great bar that attracts the great and the good from the city. Staff were very helpful and overall we had no complaints whatsoever.

Oct 14 2003	Love those pillows!	We just returned from a wonderful weekend in SF. Our stay at the Clift was great. The only thing that I can really criticize is the 5 star rating given to this hotel. I find it more on par with a 4 star. 5 star ratings to me should be luxurious, with amenties and services that go above the expected. This hotel does not have those features. The rooms are small but adequate, as are the bathrooms. We were forewarned about the lack of a dresser and/or drawers! However, that bed and those pillows made up for all these things. Good location, a good place to see and be seen.

Sep 22 2003	Loved it	We just stayed at the Clift 9-13 through 9-20. The staff was wonderful we were given two upgrades, we ended up on the top floor in a corner room, that was huge and had amazing views. The staff was very helpful, courteous, and very friendly. The city itself was very nice, a little dirty, that could be improved. The hotel is in a nice location in the middle of everything. The bed was nice and comfy. The hotel is very modern looking with a young and hip crowd at night. We will be back for sure, a true gem of San Francisco

Sep 2 2003	Worth the $175 price tag	We wanted a romantic escape and the Clift was quite appropriate. This is an old, traditionally built hotel that has been repainted and jazzed up with fun colors and theatrical lighting. The Redwood Room was charming with moving pictures on the walls just like in Harry Potter's Hogswarts school. The rooms were decent sized and very comfortable indeed and the decor minimalist yet pleasing. Minibar items are outrageously priced so bring your own. Room service is also outrageous - Asia de Cuba's appetizers begin at $18-22. I suggest for this price you are better off with a romantic and scrumptious 3 course meal at Gary Danko for $55. The front desk service was not very friendly - it caters to an "in" crowd and since we didn't look like Wallpaper models with an entourage, nobody really paid us any attention.

Aug 20 2003	Great Service with	I just returned from a 5 night stay at the Clift. I had my reservations of staying at The Clift after reading some negative feedback on this site. After the first night I knew I was staying in a hotel that values their customers.I would not recommend this hotel for families. On the weekend it is very similar to staying at a night club. The long lines outside to get into the Redwood Room identifies the popularity of this night club. Yet you would never know there is a night club below you with very well insulated room.The room was clean and very posh. The beds have silky sheets and very romantic lighting. This is an older hotel but everything is nicely updated.The staff is very friendly and approachable. Anywhere you see a staff member they always smile and say hello. I would highly recommend consulting with the Concierge to help with transportation and advice on restaurants.I highly recommend Clift for couples wanting a romantic stay in San Francisco. I would also recommend room service. Expensive but great food.

Aug 12 2003	Amazing Service!	We just got back from our Clift Hotel experience and it was awesome. I cannot stress enough how friendly and helpful the staff was. We received great recommendations, everything from the best way to get to the hotel from the airport from where to go for great meals! The experience at the Clift was exceptional and I would go back.

Jul 29 2003	Like Sleeping On A Cloud	My partner and I stayed at The Clift June 26 - 30, 2003 for Pride Weekend. We got an excellent rate through Expedia and were very pleased at most everything the hotel had to offer. Pros: Luxury bedding which makes everything else seem less significant. Artistic, creative, furnishings and details (visit the hotel's website and you may understand the artistic vision). Excellent view (ask for a corner room on the highest floor available). Extremely clean room. Very polite and attractive looking staff (always opened doors and smiling). Would have loved to visit the Redwood Room but was too busy elsewhere. Excellent location near Union Square, cable cars, subway, restaurants, theaters. Cons: It was unusually hot weekend for SF and the air in the room wasn't circulating too well. Bathroom did not seem to have a circulation fan. Room service provides any ice you need upon request but would have preferred to get my own after having to have it brought to us about 10 times. All in all an excellent place to stay if you appreciate good taste, creativity, and romance in the greatest city on the planet. Have Fun!

Jul 24 2003	The Clift Hotel is Fabulous!	Words cannot express how fabulous our stay was at The Clift Hotel! We were originally booked on the club level of the Ritz Carlton for our stay (@$375 a night) and when we checked in, the room was awful! It looked like a Hampton Inn room complete with a ceiling leak and dust on the furniture. We immediately left and switched to The Clift. Our stay was glorious. The room was large and the beds (great sheets!) were very comfortable. The fitness center was small, but top-notch equipment and the business center was excellent. The hotel is in the perfect location, a block away from Union Square. Also, as an early riser, I would wake up and go to Starbucks across the street, leaving my husband and kids in the room. Then, I would go to the Fitness Center where I enjoyed the best stairmaster ever--Cybex 800. I was in heaven for 5 nights! The staff was kind, hip and happy -- the concierge, Phillipe, was beyond compare. This is the perfect hotel in our opinion and I'm sorry its gotten such sporadic reviews. We are sold on the Ian Schrager hotels and when we have the opportunity, we will stay in them!

Jul 22 2003	Funky Fun	I believe that one's experience of the Clift depends upon one's expectations. I think the Clift delivers what it promises.I stayed there for three nights. The staff was friendly and beautiful. They were nothing but helpful. The door was opened for me everytime, my clothes were pressed and returned to me immediately, and the clerk was very welcoming after our long flight from Florida.The decor trendy and fun. Yes, the lobby was dark, but I felt that added to the intimate atmosphere in the well lit acloves and added a nice backdrop for the warm glow of the candles.The rooms were small, but decorated nicely. The bed was very comfortable.If you want the Holiday Inn experience then stay at the Holiday Inn. If you want to have a fun, casual, urban experience then the Clift is for you.
